questions.text: Two days after delivery, a newborn is brought to the physician because of a red, irritated eye with yellow discharge. She was born via vaginal delivery at 39 weeks' gestation to a 28-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1. The mother had an unmedicated delivery at home; the patient did not receive any routine postpartum medications. The mother had not seen her gynecologist since her first prenatal visit. The newborn's temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 42/min, and blood pressure is 73/53 mm Hg. Ophthalmic examination shows eyelid edema, conjunctival injection, and copious yellow mucopurulent discharge from the right eye. There is no corneal ulceration or evidence of keratitis. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?

choices.text: Oral erythromycin administered to the infant
IV ceftriaxone administered to the infant
Topical erythromycin administered to the infant
Oral doxycycline administered to the mother
Oral amoxicillin administered to the mother

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral erythromycin is the first-line treatment for chlamydial neonatal conjunctivitis, which typically occurs 5–14 days after delivery and manifests with mild eyelid swelling and watery or mucopurulent ocular discharge. This patient's presentation is consistent with NGC, for which oral erythromycin is not indicated as either prophylaxis or treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous or intramuscular ceftriaxone is the treatment of choice in infants with NGC. However, ceftriaxone is not used for NGC prophylaxis.

C) CORRECT:

Topical erythromycin ointment should be applied within 1 hour of birth to prevent NGC. In most states in the US, prophylaxis against NGC is required by law. If left untreated, NGC may result in corneal scarring and blindness. After confirming NGC (using culture and Gram stain or PCR), systemic treatment with either an IV or IM third-generation cephalosporin (e.g., ceftriaxone) is indicated. In addition, the eyes should be flushed with saline until the discharge clears.
Image Description:

The eyelids are swollen, with purulent exudate forming crusts around them. Below the crusts there may be a large reservoir of pus. Special care should be taken and safety goggles should be worn when examining the eyes.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral doxycycline may be administered to treat mothers of newborns who have newborn conjunctivitis due to an infection with Chlamydia trachomatis. However, administration of oral doxycycline (as a prophylactic measure) in pregnant women is contraindicated because it may lead to bone damage and deposits in teeth (yellowing of the primary teeth) in the offspring.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral amoxicillin can be used to treat infection with Chlamydia trachomatis in pregnant women and, therefore, help prevent chlamydial neonatal conjunctivitis (CNC). However, CNC typically occurs 5–14 days after delivery and manifests with mild eyelid swelling and watery or mucopurulent ocular discharge. This patient's presentation is more consistent with NGC. Amoxicillin is not the first-line treatment for infection with Neisseria gonorrhea and, therefore, would have not prevented this newborn's NGC.
questions.hint: This patient presents with conjunctival injection and copious yellow mucopurulent discharge 2 days after birth, all of which are consistent with neonatal gonococcal conjunctivitis (NGC). NGC is typically caused by ophthalmic colonization of the newborn's conjunctiva during delivery from mothers with Neisseria gonorrhea infection.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old primigravid woman comes to the physician in October for her first prenatal visit. She has delayed the visit because she wanted a “natural birth” but was recently convinced to get a checkup after feeling more tired than usual. She feels well. Menarche was at the age of 12 years and menses used to occur at regular 28-day intervals and last 3–7 days. The patient emigrated from Mexico 2 years ago. Her immunization records are unavailable. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 28-week gestation. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
12.4 g/dL


Leukocyte count
8000/mm3



Blood group
B negative


Serum



 Glucose
88 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL


 TSH
3.6 μU/mL


 Rapid plasma reagin
negative


 HIV antibody
negative


 Hepatitis B surface antigen
negative


Urinalysis shows no abnormalities. Urine culture is negative. Chlamydia and gonorrhea testing are negative. A Pap smear shows no abnormalities. Administration of which of the following vaccines is most appropriate at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) vaccine is not indicated in this patient because she does not have any of the risk factors for which Hib vaccine is normally indicated (e.g., asplenia). The Hib vaccine is not routinely recommended during pregnancy.

B) CORRECT:

All pregnant individuals should receive a single dose of Tdap between the 27th and 36th weeks of pregnancy. Tdap vaccine protects the mother from puerperal tetanus and the neonate from pertussis, diphtheria, and neonatal tetanus. The injectable (inactivated) form of the influenza vaccine is also indicated in pregnant individuals because an influenza infection during pregnancy is associated with a more severe infection and a higher risk of both preterm labor and fetal defects. The influenza vaccine is safe during all trimesters and should ideally be administered by the end of October (i.e., prior to the onset of the flu season, which lasts from October until May) and protects the mother and the neonate from influenza infection for up to several months after the delivery. A live, attenuated, nasal spray vaccine is also available, but only the injectable forms of the influenza vaccine should be used in this patient because live vaccines are contraindicated during pregnancy.

C) INCORRECT:

The mumps, measles, and rubella (MMR) vaccine is a live vaccine and therefore contraindicated during pregnancy.

D) INCORRECT:

The human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine is not recommended during pregnancy because the effects of the vaccine on the fetus are not fully understood.

E) INCORRECT:

The influenza vaccine is indicated for pregnant individuals because an influenza infection during pregnancy is associated with a more severe infection (e.g., pneumonia) and a higher risk of both preterm labor and fetal defects. However, in a patient at 28 weeks' gestation, another immunization should also be administered.
questions.hint: Live vaccinations are contraindicated during pregnancy.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 12 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for her initial prenatal visit. She feels well. She was treated for genital herpes one year ago and gonorrhea 3 months ago. Medications include folic acid and a multivitamin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 12-week gestation. Urine dipstick is positive for leukocyte esterase and nitrite. Urine culture shows Escherichia coli (> 100,000 colony forming units/mL). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Single-dose ceftriaxone and azithromycin is the first-line treatment for gonorrhea, which can be asymptomatic in many cases. However, if an asymptomatic infection is suspected, diagnosis (e.g., nucleic acid amplification testing) would be indicated prior to the initiation of treatment. This combination of antibiotics is not used for the treatment of asymptomatic bacteriuria during pregnancy.

B) INCORRECT:

Gentamicin should be avoided in this patient because aminoglycosides are teratogenic and can cause irreversible bilateral deafness in the fetus. While aminoglycosides may be administered in nonpregnant patients as a component of second-line treatment for pyelonephritis with either aminopenicillins and beta-lactamase inhibitors or cephalosporins, they are not generally used in the treatment of cystitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole is the first-line drug for uncomplicated cystitis in nonpregnant women and a second-line antibiotic for the treatment of urinary tract infections in pregnant women in the 2nd and 3rd trimesters (except in the last month of pregnancy). However, the drug should be avoided in this patient because trimethoprim is a folate antagonist, which may cause fetal neural tube defects in the first trimester of pregnancy.

D) INCORRECT:

Asymptomatic bacteriuria should always be treated promptly during pregnancy. This patient is at a higher risk of developing pyelonephritis from asymptomatic bacteriuria than a nonpregnant woman because, during pregnancy, the widened ureters and increased glucose levels in the urine facilitate the ascension of organisms to the kidney. Furthermore, if left untreated, there is also an increased risk of prematurity and low birth weight. In nonpregnant patients, asymptomatic bacteriuria does not require treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

Renal ultrasound can be performed to evaluate for urinary retention and signs of pyelonephritis. This pregnant patient's asymptomatic bacteriuria puts her at increased risk of developing pyelonephritis. However, she does not currently have any features that would suggest upper urinary tract involvement (e.g., flank pain, fever, or chills).

F) INCORRECT:

Ciprofloxacin is frequently used to treat complicated urinary tract infections in nonpregnant patients. However, fluoroquinolones are contraindicated during pregnancy. As there are other approved antibiotic agents, ciprofloxacin should be avoided in this pregnant patient.

G) CORRECT:

Amoxicillin/clavulanate is a first-line antibiotic agent for asymptomatic bacteriuria during pregnancy. Pregnancy increases the risk of bacteriuria and recurrent urinary tract infections because of increased pressure on the bladder from the growing uterus, urinary stasis, and immunosuppression. Screening for asymptomatic bacteriuria is recommended for all pregnant women in the first trimester. Asymptomatic bacteriuria during pregnancy should always be treated since it increases the risk of pyelonephritis in the mother, as well as preterm delivery and low birth weight.

Other antibiotic agents used to treat cystitis that are safe during pregnancy include oral cephalosporins (e.g., cefpodoxime, cephalexin), fosfomycin, and nitrofurantoin (during the 2nd and 3rd trimesters). Follow-up urine culture is recommended 1–2 weeks after completion of treatment to ensure eradication of bacteriuria.
questions.hint: This patient has no urinary frequency or dysuria, but her urinalysis is positive for leukocyte esterase and nitrite, and her urine culture grows E. coli, all of which indicates asymptomatic bacteriuria.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 37 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labor. Her current pregnancy has been complicated by iron deficiency anemia treated with iron tablets. She has received routine prenatal care, but she has not been tested for group B streptococcal (GBS) colonization. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child were complicated by an infection with GBS that resulted in sepsis in the newborn. The patient has no history of serious illness. Current medications include folic acid and a multivitamin. Vital signs are within normal limits. The abdomen is nontender and contractions are felt every 4 minutes. There is clear amniotic fluid pooling in the vagina. The fetus is in a cephalic presentation. The fetal heart rate is 140/min. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain vaginal-rectal swab for GBS culture and intravenous penicillin administration
Obtain vaginal-rectal swab for GBS culture
Obtain vaginal-rectal swab for nucleic acid amplification testing and intravenous penicillin administration

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Culture of GBS is usually indicated at 36 0/7–37 6/7 weeks' gestation for diagnosis of maternal GBS colonization. Intrapartum administration of intravenous penicillin G is used for the prophylaxis of neonatal GBS infection. Indications for prophylaxis include maternal GBS colonization, GBS bacteriuria occurring during pregnancy, or a history of a previous newborn with GBS infection (as in this patient). Because this patient already has an indication for prophylaxis, GBS screening cultures are not required.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient is most likely colonized by GBS and should receive a different intervention to avoid intrapartum transmission and a subsequent negative outcome in her unborn child.

C) INCORRECT:

Culture of GBS is indicated at 36 0/7–37 6/7 weeks' gestation for diagnosis of maternal GBS colonization. However, patients with GBS bacteriuria during pregnancy or a history of a previous newborn with GBS infection (as in this patient) require prophylaxis. Therefore, she does not require further testing, as it would not influence the treatment.

D) CORRECT:

Intrapartum administration of intravenous penicillin G is used for the prophylaxis of neonatal GBS infection. Maternal GBS colonization is a major risk factor for early-onset neonatal infection and sepsis. Routine screening for GBS colonization of all pregnant women via culture of vaginal and rectal swabs is indicated between 36 0/7–37 6/7 weeks' gestation. Women with GBS bacteriuria occurring anytime during pregnancy or history of a previous newborn with GBS infection, as in this patient, should receive routine prophylactic antibiotics and do not have to undergo prior screening for GBS colonization.

Other maternal risk factors for GBS infection that serve as indications for antibiotic prophylaxis in patients with unknown antepartum culture status include fever, preterm labor, premature rupture of membranes, or positive intrapartum nucleic acid amplification testing for GBS.

E) INCORRECT:

Nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) can be used for rapid intrapartum diagnosis of maternal GBS colonization in women with an unknown culture status. However, NAAT is not routinely used because of its low sensitivity compared to standard GBS culture. Moreover, the management of cases with a possible maternal GBS colonization and an unknown antepartum culture status should be based on maternal risk factors rather than NAAT results. Intrapartum administration of intravenous penicillin G is used for the prophylaxis of neonatal GBS infection.

F) INCORRECT:

Colonization or active infections (e.g., chorioamnionitis) do not routinely justify a cesarean delivery. However, if an infection presents along with fetal distress or there is any other standard obstetric indication (e.g., insufficient maternal contractions), the patient would require a cesarean delivery.
questions.hint: This patient's first child had sepsis due to a GBS infection. It is essential to prevent the infection from recurring in her second child.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old primigravid woman comes for a follow-up prenatal visit at 18 weeks' gestation. Ultrasonography at 12 weeks' gestation showed a nuchal translucency above the 99th percentile. At that visit, pregnancy-associated plasma protein A was decreased to 2 standard deviations below the mean. A chorionic villus sampling was performed, which showed a 47, XX karyotype. At today's visit, vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with an 18-week gestation. Ultrasonography shows shortened femur length, shortened middle phalanges of the fifth digits with clinodactyly, and a hypoplastic nasal bone. A quad screening test would most likely show which of the following sets of findings?



α-Fetoprotein
Estriol
β-hCG
Inhibin A



A
Decreased
decreased
increased
increased


B
Normal
normal
normal
normal


C
Decreased
decreased
decreased
decreased


D
Decreased
decreased
decreased
normal


E
Increased
normal
normal
normal
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The quad screen test should be performed at 15–22 weeks' gestation and can help to diagnose Down syndrome and other fetal aneuploidies (e.g., trisomy 18), as well as open neural tube and abdominal wall defects. Down syndrome pregnancies are associated with significantly decreased α-fetoprotein and free estriol levels and a marked increase in β-hCG and inhibin A levels in the maternal serum (see “Overview of quad and triple screening tests” table).

In addition to increased nuchal translucency and decreased PAPP-A levels, first trimester screening in a Down syndrome pregnancy would show increased β-hCG levels.

B) INCORRECT:

Normal findings in all quad screen markers are consistent with a normal fetus but are concerning for trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome) in a fetus with a suspected aneuploidy (based on the 47, XX karyotype). While Patau syndrome can also manifest with increased nuchal translucency and decreased PAPP-A during first-trimester screening, as well as a 47, XX karyotype, this patient's shortened femur length, shortened fifth digits with clinodactyly, and hypoplastic nasal bone are indicative of Down syndrome. Ultrasound findings suggestive of Patau syndrome include rocker-bottom feet, microcephaly or holoprosencephaly, and polydactyly (rather than clinodactyly).

C) INCORRECT:

A mild decrease in all quad screen markers is consistent with Turner syndrome. Though Turner syndrome can also manifest with increased nuchal translucency (due to lymphatic dysplasia), shortened femur length, and decreased PAPP-A levels, this patient's chorionic villus sampling showed a 47, XX karyotype, which is not consistent with the 45, XO karyotype that is characteristic of Turner syndrome.

A decrease in all quad screen markers is also consistent with trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome), though inhibin A can also be normal in this condition. While Edwards syndrome can also manifest with increased nuchal translucency and decreased PAPP-A during first-trimester screening, as well as a 47, XX karyotype, this patient's shortened femur length, shortened fifth digits with clinodactyly, and hypoplastic nasal bone are indicative of Down syndrome. Ultrasound findings typical of Edwards syndrome include rocker-bottom feet and clenched fists with overlapping of the third and fourth digits by the second and fifth digits, respectively (rather than clinodactyly).

D) INCORRECT:

A decrease in α-fetoprotein, free estriol, and β-hCG with normal or decreased inhibin A is consistent with trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome). While Edwards syndrome can also manifest with increased nuchal translucency and decreased PAPP-A during first-trimester screening, as well as a 47, XX karyotype, this patient's shortened femur length, shortened fifth digits with clinodactyly, and hypoplastic nasal bone are indicative of Down syndrome. Ultrasound findings typical of Edwards syndrome include rocker-bottom feet and clenched fists with overlapping of the third and fourth digits by the second and fifth digits, respectively (rather than clinodactyly).

E) INCORRECT:

An isolated increase in α-fetoprotein during pregnancy is characteristic of fetal neural tube defects or open abdominal wall defects such as gastroschisis or omphalocele. While some of these defects (such as omphalocele) may be associated with an increase in nuchal translucency, first-trimester fetal screening would show normal PAPP-A levels and a 46, XX karyotype. Furthermore, none of these conditions would involve shortened femur length, shortened fifth digits with clinodactyly, or a hypoplastic nasal bone.
questions.hint: Increased nuchal translucency, decreased pregnancy-associated plasma protein A (PAPP-A) levels, shortened femur length, shortened fifth digits with clinodactyly, and a hypoplastic nasal bone in a fetus with a 47, XX karyotype are features highly suggestive of trisomy 21 (Down syndrome).

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, comes to the physician for her first prenatal visit. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child were uncomplicated. She is not sure about the date of her last menstrual period. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 10-week gestation. An ultrasound examination confirms the gestational age and shows one fetus with no indication of multiple gestations. During counseling on pregnancy risks and possible screening and diagnostic tests, the patient states she would like to undergo screening for Down syndrome. She wants to undergo screening immediately and would prefer a reliable screening method with a low risk to herself and the fetus. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management at this time?

choices.text: Maternal serum α-fetoprotein, human chorionic gonadotropin, unconjugated estriol, and inhibin A

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Maternal serum α-fetoprotein, human chorionic gonadotropin, unconjugated estriol, and inhibin A are all assessed in quad screening. These results can help determine the statistical risk for several aneuploidies, including Down syndrome, and other fetal anomalies such as abdominal wall or neural tube defects. The test carries no notable risks for mother and child. However, the quad screen test is done between weeks 15–22 of pregnancy. Other, equally safe screening options for Down syndrome could be done sooner.

B) INCORRECT:

Amniocentesis is indicated as a prenatal invasive diagnostic procedure to further confirm fetal genetic abnormalities in patients with abnormal screening results. However, it is usually only performed starting at 15 weeks' gestation, as it is associated with a high risk of complications in the first trimester. This patient is only 10 weeks pregnant and has additionally specifically requested a low-risk test. She should not undergo amniocentesis at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

Nuchal translucency scan is an ultrasound procedure used to evaluate the fluid-filled space on the posterior aspect of the fetal neck. Increased nuchal translucency is associated with an increased risk of fetal aneuploidy and/or structural anomalies (e.g., neural tube defects). Nuchal translucency alone, however, is a poor predictor of fetal aneuploidy and should rather be used in addition to pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A and human chorionic gonadotropin as part of the first-trimester combined screening method performed between weeks 10–14 of pregnancy.

D) CORRECT:

Cell-free fetal DNA testing (cffDNA testing) of maternal blood is the most sensitive (> 99%) and specific (> 99%) screening method for Down syndrome and can be performed from 9–10 weeks' gestation onwards. A maternal age ≥ 35 years puts this patient at high risk for fetal aneuploidies, and cffDNA testing is the best option if she wants to undergo screening immediately. If cffDNA testing indicates an increased risk for Down syndrome, chorionic villus sampling will have to be performed for a definitive diagnosis between 10–13 weeks of gestation.

E) INCORRECT:

Chorionic villus sampling (CVS) is indicated as a prenatal invasive diagnostic procedure to further confirm fetal genetic abnormalities in patients with abnormal screening results between 10–13 weeks of gestation. Although this patient is at 10 weeks' gestation, CVS should only be performed after a screening test because there is a small risk of complications involved.
questions.hint: This patient requires a noninvasive screening test of high sensitivity and specificity for Down syndrome that can be performed at 10 weeks' gestation.

questions.text: A 37-year-old primigravid woman comes to the physician at 13 weeks' gestation for a prenatal visit. She feels well. Her only medication is folic acid. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 13-week gestation. Ultrasonography shows a nuchal translucency above the 99th percentile. Maternal serum pregnancy-associated plasma protein A is decreased and human chorionic gonadotropin concentrations are elevated to 2 times the median level. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Chorionic villus sampling for fetal chromosomal analysis is the method of choice to confirm fetal aneuploidy at 10 to 13 weeks' gestation and should be offered to all patients at increased risk (e.g., abnormal first-trimester screening, maternal age ≥ 35 years, previous child with a chromosomal anomaly). From the 15th week of pregnancy onward, amniocentesis is the preferred method for prenatal genetic diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

The quadruple marker test is performed at 15–22 weeks' gestation and involves measurements of alpha-fetoprotein, unconjugated estriol, β-hCG, and inhibin A in maternal serum to screen for fetal chromosomal disorders. Since this patient's first-trimester screening already indicated a risk for Down syndrome, more definitive testing rather than further screening should be performed.

C) INCORRECT:

Cell-free fetal DNA (cffDNA) testing of maternal blood can be used to screen for fetal aneuploidies. Because of its low false-positive rate for Down syndrome, cffDNA testing is commonly used as a secondary screening test in patients at high risk (e.g., maternal age ≥ 35 years, abnormal first-trimester screening results) in order to avoid invasive procedures. However, cffDNA testing is not diagnostic and fetal chromosomal analysis using an invasive test is still required to confirm Down syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

The triple screening test takes into account serum levels of α-fetoprotein, unconjugated estriol, and β-hCG (free or total). It should be performed in the second trimester, usually between 15–22 weeks of gestation. Since this patient's first-trimester screening already indicated a risk for Down syndrome, more definitive testing rather than further screening should be performed.

E) INCORRECT:

Amniocentesis is indicated as a prenatal diagnostic procedure to further evaluate for fetal genetic abnormalities in patients with abnormal screening results. However, it is usually only performed at 15–20 weeks of gestation, as it is associated with a high risk of complications in the first trimester. This patient is only 13 weeks pregnant and should therefore not undergo amniocentesis.
questions.hint: Increased nuchal translucency, elevated β-hCG levels, and decreased pregnancy-associated plasma protein A (PAPP-A) indicate a high risk of Down syndrome.

questions.text: A 27-year-old primigravid woman at 32 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. She has had swollen legs, mild shortness of breath, and generalized fatigue for the past 2 weeks. Medications include iron supplements and a multivitamin. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 93/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 108/60 mm Hg. There is 2+ pitting edema of the lower extremities, but no erythema or tenderness. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows an S3 gallop. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 32-week gestation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Echocardiography is a useful test for diagnosing heart failure or cardiac disease. Although this patient presents with peripheral edema, a third heart sound, and shortness of breath, these are common findings in healthy pregnancies. In addition, her vital signs are normal, there is no underlying history of heart disease, and there are no worrisome signs for heart failure (e.g., new pulmonary edema, worsening shortness of breath). Therefore, echocardiography is not warranted.

B) INCORRECT:

This was a very good option to consider because a urinalysis would likely be conducted in this patient! The exam will often have questions in which some options have some degree of truth. In this case, it is important to recognize that although urinalysis is an essential part of prenatal checkups for detecting bacteriuria or proteinuria (e.g., indicating pre-eclampsia), screening for proteinuria is not warranted as the next best step of management for this patient's symptoms because she is normotensive. Her lower extremity edema and shortness of breath are common findings in healthy pregnancies. Additional workup for pre-eclampsia would not be warranted unless she developed worrisome findings (e.g., hypertension, facial edema, weight gain, headache, visual symptoms, or oliguria). With that said, a urinalysis would likely be conducted in this patient to rule out asymptomatic bacteriuria as part of her routine prenatal visit.

C) INCORRECT:

A lower extremity doppler is a highly sensitive ultrasound test used for the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Pregnancy increases the risk of DVT. Although DVT may present with lower extremity edema, it is generally confined to one leg and also presents with warmth and tenderness. Because this patient lacks other signs of DVT, a lower extremity doppler is unnecessary at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

The D-dimer level is used to rule out pulmonary embolism or deep vein thrombosis (DVT) when clinical likelihood is low but worrisome symptoms (e.g., shortness of breath and/or chest pain) are present. Although this patient presents with lower extremity edema, it is not unilateral as would be expected from a DVT. Her heart rate, respirations, and blood pressure are also all within normal range, which makes pulmonary embolism less likely.

E) INCORRECT:

A ventilation-perfusion scan is useful for diagnosing pulmonary embolism in patients with renal insufficiency, or in those with contrast allergy who cannot undergo CT pulmonary angiography. This patient does not have any signs that are worrisome for pulmonary embolism (e.g., tachycardia, pleuritic chest pain) and her mild shortness of breath is a common occurrence in late pregnancy.

F) CORRECT:

This patient at 32 weeks' gestation presents with physiological changes of pregnancy (peripheral edema, shortness of breath, fatigue, and a third heart sound) that should be addressed with reassurance and monitoring. Sodium retention and blood volume expansion are some of the most important hemodynamic adaptations that occur during pregnancy. In many healthy women, this adaptation will lead to peripheral edema that manifests as swollen legs. In later stages of pregnancy, this can worsen as the gravid uterus can compress the inferior vena cava and the iliac veins. Similarly, subjective shortness of breath, fatigue, and a third heart sound are seen in most healthy pregnancies, especially in the later stages.
questions.hint: In the later stages of pregnancy, the gravid uterus often puts pressure on the inferior vena cava and the iliac veins.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the physician for preconceptional advice. She has been married for 2 years and would like to conceive within the next year. Menses occur at regular 30-day intervals and last 4 days with normal flow. She does not smoke or drink alcohol and follows a balanced diet. She takes no medications. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 55 kg (121 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Physical examination, including pelvic examination, shows no abnormalities. She has adequate knowledge of the fertile days of her menstrual cycle. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient at this time?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Supplementation of folic acid (0.4–0.8 mg/day) is recommended in all patients trying to conceive. Ideally, women should begin taking a supplement ≥ 4 weeks before trying to conceive and continue with this dose until 12 weeks of gestational age to meet the increased demand of folate due to fetal neural tube development and maternal and fetal erythropoiesis. If there is a folate deficiency, neural tube defects (e.g., anencephaly, meningomyelocele) and megaloblastic anemia may occur.

B) INCORRECT:

In the absence of severe deficiency, excessive intake of vitamin A is contraindicated in pregnant women and women who may become pregnant within the next 60 days. Vitamin A doses greater than the recommended dietary allowance in pregnancy (> 770 mcg/day or > 2560 units/day) may cause craniofacial malformations or central nervous system, heart, or thymus abnormalities in the fetus.

C) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 supplementation is recommended for pregnant women who adhere to a vegan diet since vitamin B12 is mainly found in red meat, fish, and dairy products. Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to maternal and fetal megaloblastic anemia. This patient does not follow a vegan diet and is not yet pregnant, making vitamin B12 supplementation unnecessary.

D) INCORRECT:

Iron supplementation of 30–60 mg/d is recommended during pregnancy to meet the increased iron demand due to maternal and fetal erythropoiesis. Iron deficiency in pregnancy may cause maternal and fetal anemia and increases the risk of placental insufficiency. Since this patient shows no symptoms of iron deficiency anemia, such as fatigue or pallor, iron supplementation is not necessary prior to conception.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients who are underweight can experience difficulty conceiving. If the patient were underweight and having problems becoming pregnant, gaining weight might be advised. Gaining extra weight prior to conception is not necessary in this case, as the woman has a normal BMI. Over the course of pregnancy, she should gain 25–35 lbs (about 11–16 kg).
questions.hint: Which of the following is most likely to decrease the risk of neural tube defects such as spina bifida and anencephaly in the fetus?

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 24 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. She feels well. Her earlier pregnancy was uncomplicated. This is her 4th prenatal visit. She had an ultrasound scan 2 weeks ago that showed a live intrauterine pregnancy consistent with a 22-week gestation with no anomalies. She had a normal Pap smear 2 years ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 24-week gestation. Her blood group and type is B positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Serum pregnancy-associated plasma protein A and hCG level
Swab for Group B streptococcus culture

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serum pregnancy-associated plasma protein A and hCG levels (in combination with ultrasound measurement of nuchal translucency) are part of first-trimester screening for congenital abnormalities and are usually performed between 10–14 weeks' gestation.

B) CORRECT:

Screening for gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) with an oral glucose challenge test is recommended for every pregnant patient at 24–28 weeks' gestation, or earlier in patients with increased risk of undiagnosed type 2 diabetes (e.g., due to obesity and GDM in a previous pregnancy). Early diagnosis and treatment of gestational diabetes mellitus are important to prevent complications of this condition, including gestational hypertension, preeclampsia, and shoulder dystocia due to fetal macrosomia.

C) INCORRECT:

Rh antibody testing should be performed in all Rh-negative pregnant women between 28–29 weeks' gestation to screen for circulating Rh antibodies. Although screening can be performed earlier, Rh antibody testing is not necessary for this Rh-positive patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Screening for Group B streptococcus (GBS) by vaginal and rectal swab is performed at 36–37+6 weeks' gestation to evaluate for colonization that could potentially lead to neonatal infection or chorioamnionitis. Women who are positive for GBS should be treated with intrapartum penicillin G, or clindamycin or erythromycin in patients allergic to penicillin.

E) INCORRECT:

Biophysical profile is used to screen for pregnancies where there is an increased risk of antenatal fetal death. It is generally performed after 32 weeks' gestation.

F) INCORRECT:

Tdap vaccination is usually performed between 27–36 weeks' gestation, to booster maternal immunity to pertussis and to maximize the passive transfer of protective antibodies to the neonate.
questions.hint: At 24–28 weeks' gestation, screening for a condition associated with fetal macrosomia is recommended.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of nausea for the last two weeks. During this period, she has had increased urinary frequency and fatigue. She also reports two episodes of nonbloody vomiting. There is no personal history of serious illness. Her last menstrual period was 8 weeks ago. Physical examination shows bilateral breast tenderness. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is positive. Which of the following is the most accurate predictor of gestational age?

choices.text: Ratio of head to abdominal circumference

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The ratio of head to abdominal circumference is used to differentiate asymmetrical from symmetrical intrauterine growth restriction (the ratio is increased in asymmetrical intrauterine growth restriction) but is not used to assess gestational age.

B) INCORRECT:

During early pregnancy, the levels of serum β-hCG double every 2.5 days, reaching a maximum level between 100,000 and 200,000 mIU/mL ∼ 60–70 days after implantation. Subsequently, the levels of β-hCG decrease to 10,000–20,000 IU/mL by the middle of the second trimester and remain constant thereafter. Moreover, spontaneous abortion can cause a lower-than-expected level of β-hCG while twin pregnancies, gestational trophoblastic disease, and fetal trisomy can cause a higher-than-expected level. Given this overall variability in the levels of β-hCG levels during pregnancy, it cannot be used to accurately estimate the gestational age.

C) INCORRECT:

The fetal femoral length cannot be used to estimate the fetal gestational age during the first trimester because femoral development only begins by 9 weeks and is usually not completed before 11 weeks. In this pregnant woman with her last menstrual period 8 weeks ago, the formation of limb buds would have probably just begun. The fetal femoral length can be used to estimate gestational age after 14 weeks.

D) INCORRECT:

The first day of the last menstrual period can be used to estimate the gestational age and/or EDD. But such an estimate of gestational age is error-prone because it assumes that all menstrual cycles last 28 days and that ovulation always occurs in the middle of the cycle (at 14 days). Also, many patients do not recall the exact date of their last menstrual period, and some patients may report the mild vaginal spotting that may occur as a result of implantation bleeding as their period.

E) INCORRECT:

The mean diameter of the gestational sac (mean sac diameter) can give a rough estimate of the gestational age, but the margin of error by this measurement is larger than that calculated by a different biometric parameter on ultrasonography; the use of mean sac diameter to date pregnancy is therefore not recommended.

During early pregnancy (3–5 weeks), the gestational sac is visible but the embryo may not be seen; in such a scenario the mean sac diameter may be recorded to document pregnancy.

F) INCORRECT:

The symphisiofundal height (SFH) in a normal pregnancy does correlate with the duration of gestation. However, other factors such as the position of the umbilicus, the amount of fat in the abdominal wall, patient height, the fullness of the rectum or bladder, and deviations from normal pregnancy (e.g., poly-/oligohydramnios, intrauterine growth retardation, macrosomia, twin gestation) can affect SFH; SFH is therefore not a very accurate estimator of gestational age. Moreover, SFH cannot be measured this early in pregnancy since the fundus of the uterus is only palpable after 12 weeks of gestation.

G) CORRECT:

Ultrasonographic measurement of crown-rump length (CRL) is the single most accurate method of estimating the gestational age in the first trimester (margin of error ± 5–7 days). In gestations < 9 weeks, if the EDD derived from CRL differs from that calculated by the last menstrual period by more than 5 days, the EDD should be changed to correspond to the value obtained by CRL measurement. This step is important because a wrong gestational age/EDD can influence pregnancy outcomes at the end of gestation (e.g., increased incidence of induction of labor by misclassifying the pregnancy as post term).

After 14 weeks of gestation (CRL > 84 mm), the accuracy of CRL in predicting gestational age decreases because of progressive curvature in the longitudinal axis of the fetus. At this stage, other measures such as biparietal diameter, head circumference, abdominal circumference, and femoral length are used to estimate the gestational age if dating was not done during the first trimester. These measures are less accurate than CRL for estimating the gestational age (margin of error ± 1–2 weeks). Beyond 20 weeks, the margin of error is large for all biometric parameters (± 3 weeks).
Image Description:

Ultrasound pelvis (transvaginal; transverse plane)

A gestational sac (red line) within the uterus contains an embryo with a crown-rump length of 11.7 mm (green overlay), indicating normal development.

H) INCORRECT:

The fetal biparietal diameter gives the best estimate of gestational age between 14 and 20 weeks, but is unreliable before this period.
questions.hint: There are several methods of determining the gestational age and estimated date of delivery (EDD). However, one of these methods is especially accurate during the first trimester.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman comes to the physician because she had a positive pregnancy test at home. For the past 3 weeks, she has had nausea and increased urinary frequency. She also had three episodes of nonbloody vomiting. She attends college and is on the varsity soccer team. She runs 45 minutes daily and lifts weights for strength training for 1 hour three times per week. She also reports that she wants to renew her ski pass for the upcoming winter season. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. After having ascertained that the patient wants to keep the pregnancy, which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation?

choices.text: Continue playing soccer, continue strength training, and do not buy a ski pass
Stop playing soccer, stop strength training, and do not buy a ski pass
Continue playing soccer, stop strength training, and do not buy a ski pass
Stop playing soccer, continue strength training, and buy a ski pass
Stop playing soccer, continue strength training, and do not buy a ski pass
Continue playing soccer, stop strength training, and buy a ski pass

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Physical activity is beneficial for pregnant patients, but adjustments may be needed to maintain a safe environment. Contact sports, such as soccer, and sports with increased risk of falling, like skiing, should be avoided, whereas running and strength training are acceptable.

B) INCORRECT:

Physical activity is beneficial for pregnant patients, but adjustments may be needed to maintain a safe environment. Contact sports, such as soccer, and sports with increased risk of falling, like skiing, should be avoided, whereas running and strength training are acceptable.

C) INCORRECT:

Physical activity is beneficial for pregnant patients, but adjustments may be needed to maintain a safe environment. Contact sports, such as soccer, and sports with increased risk of falling, like skiing, should be avoided, whereas running and strength training are acceptable.

D) INCORRECT:

Physical activity is beneficial for pregnant patients, but adjustments may be needed to maintain a safe environment. Contact sports, such as soccer, and sports with increased risk of falling, like skiing, should be avoided, whereas running and strength training are acceptable.

E) CORRECT:

While physical activity is beneficial for most pregnant individuals, contact sports (e.g., soccer), sports with increased risk of falling (e.g., skiing), activities associated with high risk of dehydration (e.g., hot yoga), and extreme sports (e.g., skydiving) should be avoided. Activities such as running, strength training (in patients with training experience before pregnancy), racquet sports, swimming, and pilates are considered safe during uncomplicated pregnancies (see “Safe and unsafe sports during pregnancy” table).

Some preexisting or obstetric medical conditions, such as hemodynamically significant heart disease, restrictive lung disease, severe anemia, and cervical insufficiency, constitute absolute contradictions to exercise during pregnancy. Relative contraindications include chronic bronchitis, poorly controlled diabetes mellitus type 1, and intrauterine growth restriction.

F) INCORRECT:

Physical activity is beneficial for pregnant patients, but adjustments may be needed to maintain a safe environment. Contact sports, such as soccer, and sports with increased risk of falling, like skiing, should be avoided, whereas running and strength training are acceptable.
questions.hint: Regular physical activity is recommended during pregnancy. However, there are certain unsafe activities that pregnant individuals should avoid.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 32 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. She feels that her baby's movements have decreased recently. She says that she used to feel 10–12 movements/hour earlier, but that it has decreased to about 7–8/hour since the day before. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child were uncomplicated. Medications include folic acid and a multivitamin. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), and blood pressure is 108/60 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 32-week gestation. The fetus is in a transverse lie. The fetal heart rate is 134/min. A 14-minute recording of the nonstress test is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Extend the nonstress test by 20 minutes

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In this patient with a single episode of decreased fetal movements, a reactive NST, and no maternal comorbidities, weekly NSTs are not necessary. A weekly NST would be indicated for recurrent episodes of decreased fetal movements and in high-risk conditions such as gestational hypertension or diabetes mellitus, a history of recurrent pregnancy loss, intrauterine growth restriction, oligohydramnios, post-term pregnancy, and certain maternal comorbidities (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus, antiphospholid syndrome).

B) INCORRECT:

Repositioning the mother in the left or right lateral decubitus position would be indicated if the NST had shown a nonreassuring fetal heart tracing; a different step is indicated in this patient with a reactive NST.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's NST shows a normal fetal heart rate (FHR) baseline of approx. 130 bpm with physiological variability (oscillation amplitude around the baseline of approx. 20–25 bpm), 4 accelerations within 14 minutes, and no decelerations, all of which indicate a reassuring fetal heart tracing and fetal well-being. In patients like this one with a single episode of decreased fetal movements (DFMs) and an otherwise uncomplicated pregnancy, reassurance and continuation of routine prenatal care are indicated. In addition, patients should continue to monitor fetal movements and reach out to their provider if they experience recurrent DFM.

D) INCORRECT:

A biophysical profile should be performed if the patient had a nonreactive NST; a different step is indicated for this patient with a reassuring fetal heart tracing.

E) INCORRECT:

A reactive NST indicates fetal well-being. Induction of labor (e.g., with IV oxytocin) is contraindicated if the gestational age is < 37 weeks (preterm) and both the mother and fetus are well. A preterm delivery increases the risk of fetal complications (e.g., neonatal respiratory distress syndrome, neonatal sepsis).

F) INCORRECT:

If this patient's NST showed decreased fetal heart rate (FHR) variability (i.e., oscillation of < 6 bpm around the FHR baseline) or < 2 accelerations within a span of 20 minutes, vibroacoustic stimulation would be performed in order to rule out fetal sleep as the cause of fetal nonreactivity. Vibroacoustic stimulation is not necessary in this patient with normal FHR variability and a reactive NST.

G) INCORRECT:

The NST will be performed for another 20 minutes if < 2 accelerations are seen within a 20-minute period. This patient's NST shows 4 accelerations within a period of 14 minutes, which indicates a reactive NST; the NST can therefore be discontinued.
questions.hint: A nonstress test (NST) is considered reactive if there are ≥ 2 fetal heart rate accelerations that last for at least 15 seconds and are > 15 bpm above the baseline within a 20-minute period.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 16 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a routine prenatal visit. She feels well. She has no history of serious illness. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 10 years but quit when she learned she was pregnant. She does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Her mother has type 1 diabetes mellitus, and her father has asthma. Current medications include a prenatal multivitamin. She appears well. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:


Alpha-fetoprotein
decreased


Unconjugated estriol
decreased


Human chorionic gonadotropin
increased


Inhibin A
increased


During counseling regarding the potential for fetal abnormalities, the patient says that she would like a definitive diagnosis as quickly as possible. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Reassurance is not appropriate for a patient who has a second-trimester quadruple test result that indicates that the fetus may have Down syndrome. Patients in this situation may desire additional diagnostic testing and/or pregnancy termination. Because this patient expressed her desire to find a definitive diagnosis, further testing and counseling should be offered.

B) INCORRECT:

Cell-free fetal DNA (cffDNA) testing of maternal blood can be used to screen for fetal aneuploidies such as Down syndrome. Because of its low false-positive rate for Down syndrome, cffDNA testing is commonly used as a secondary screening test in patients at high risk (e.g., maternal age ≥ 35 years, abnormal screening results) in order to avoid invasive procedures. However, cffDNA testing is not diagnostic and fetal chromosomal analysis using an invasive test is still required to confirm Down syndrome.

C) CORRECT:

Amniocentesis for fetal chromosomal analysis is the method of choice to confirm fetal aneuploidy in patients at ≥ 15 weeks' gestation and should be offered to all patients at increased risk (e.g., abnormal screening results, maternal age ≥ 35 years, previous child with a chromosomal anomaly). Complications of amniocentesis include miscarriage (< 0.5%), premature rupture of the membranes, fetal-maternal hemorrhage, and infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Serum pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A) is one component of first-trimester screening. Although the first-trimester combined test is the earliest screening test that can be performed (at 10 weeks' gestation), the second-trimester quadruple test that this patient has undergone has greater accuracy in later gestational ages. An isolated serum PAPP-A measurement would not provide additional information.

E) INCORRECT:

Although chorionic villus sampling can be performed to obtain fetal DNA for establishing the diagnosis of Down syndrome, it is typically performed between 10–13 weeks' gestation and would not be the preferred confirmatory test at 16 weeks' gestation.

F) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound is an essential component of prenatal aneuploidy screening but is not used for confirmatory testing. It is used in first-trimester screening (nuchal translucency measurement) and subsequent second-trimester serum testing (quadruple test or triple screen), or during the integrated screening process (nuchal translucency with quadruple screening). Findings that suggest a diagnosis of Down syndrome during the second trimester include nuchal fold thickness ≥ 6 mm, intracardiac hyperechogenic focus, and structural malformations. This patient has already undergone a screening test, which was positive; pelvic ultrasound would not be used to confirm a diagnosis of Down syndrome.
questions.hint: On the second-trimester screening test (quadruple test), the combination of increased hCG, increased inhibin A, decreased unconjugated estriol, and decreased alpha-fetoprotein indicates a high risk of Down syndrome.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 33 weeks' gestation comes to her doctor for a routine visit. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated. She has systemic lupus erythematosus and has had no flares during her pregnancy. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Current medications include iron, vitamin supplements, and hydroxychloroquine. Her temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 134/70 mm Hg. She appears well. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Ultrasonography of the fetus shows one rhythmic breathing episode for > 30 seconds within a 1-hour period, one distinct body movement and one episode of extremity extension within 30 minutes, and a deepest vertical pocket of amniotic fluid of 2.5 cm. A nonstress test shows one heart rate acceleration associated with movement over a period of 30 minutes. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discontinue hydroxychloroquine and continue close monitoring
Administer corticosteroids and continue close monitoring

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cesarean delivery is not indicated in this patient, since a vaginal delivery is possible with a BPP score of 4 without being risky for the mother or fetus. Vaginal delivery is generally safer with fewer postoperative complications and a shorter recovery period. Indications for cesarean delivery include severe fetal bradycardia, acidosis, and fetal growth restriction with circulatory depression.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) are at increased risk of preterm birth, hypertensive complications, intrauterine growth restriction, fetal atrioventricular block, and miscarriage, which makes close monitoring essential. However, hydroxychloroquine is safe in pregnancy and should not be interrupted in this patient with SLE to avoid new flares in disease activity.

C) INCORRECT:

Close monitoring with concomitant administration of corticosteroids to induce fetal lung maturity is a management option in patients with a BPP score ≤ 4 who are at less than 32 weeks' gestation. Another intervention is required for this patient at 33 weeks' gestation.

D) CORRECT:

Induction of labor with oxytocin is indicated in all patients with a total BPP score ≤ 4 points at ≥ 32 weeks of gestation who have no contraindications to vaginal birth. A low BPP score indicates a high risk of fetal asphyxia within one week if the fetus remains undelivered. Vaginal birth is preferred over cesarean delivery because it has fewer postoperative complications and a shorter recovery period. In addition, all patients at less than 34 weeks' gestation expected to deliver within the next 7 days should receive corticosteroids to accelerate fetal lung maturity and help prevent neonatal respiratory distress syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Reassurance with expectant management is not appropriate in a patient with a BPP score of ≤ 4, which may indicate potential fetal compromise (e.g., deficient oxygen supply and metabolic acidosis) that requires further intervention to prevent fetal death.
questions.hint: Biophysical profile (BPP) is performed in high-risk pregnancies (e.g., maternal systemic lupus erythematosus) to assess the risk of antenatal fetal death. BPP measures parameters of breathing, tone, movement, amniotic fluid volume, and heart rate reactivity to movements (nonstress test). Each parameter receives a score of either 0 (abnormal) or 2 points (normal). Although this fetus has adequate tone (at least one episode of extremity extension within 30 minutes) and a deepest vertical pocket of amniotic fluid of ≥ 2 cm, all other parameters are abnormal, resulting in a BPP score of 4/10 points.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravid woman at 10 weeks' gestation comes to her physician accompanied by her husband for her first prenatal visit. She has no personal or family history of serious illness. Her vaccinations are up-to-date and she takes no medications. She has no history of illicit drug use and does not drink alcohol. Her vital signs are within normal limits. She is 167 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 68 kg (150 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. She tested negative for HIV, Chlamydia trachomatis, and Neisseria gonorrhoeae 4 years ago. Testing for which of the following infections should be performed at this visit?

choices.text: Group B streptococci, syphilis, tuberculosis, and HIV
Hepatitis C, hepatitis B, cytomegalovirus, and herpes simplex virus
Group B streptococci, tuberculosis, cytomegalovirus, and herpes simplex virus
HIV, syphilis, hepatitis B, and hepatitis C
No infection testing is necessary at this visit

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Screening for syphilis and HIV is recommended for all pregnant individuals at the first prenatal visit. Prenatal screening for Group B streptococcus is performed between 36 0/7 and 37 6/7 weeks of gestation. Screening for tuberculosis is recommended only in patients with risk factors for TB.

B) INCORRECT:

Screening for hepatitis C and hepatitis B is recommended in all pregnant individuals at the first prenatal visit. Screening for herpes simplex virus is not routinely performed; testing is indicated in patients with active genital ulcers. Screening for cytomegalovirus is not recommended during pregnancy because serological tests cannot distinguish between recurrent and primary infection (which poses a greater risk to the fetus), antibody titers cannot predict transmission to the fetus, and treatment of the mother does not prevent neonatal infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Prenatal screening for Group B streptococcus is performed between 36 0/7 and 37 6/7 weeks of gestation. Screening for tuberculosis is recommended only in patients with risk factors for TB. Screening for herpes simplex virus is not routinely performed; testing is indicated in patients with active genital ulcers. Screening for cytomegalovirus is not recommended during pregnancy because serological tests cannot distinguish between recurrent and primary infection (which poses a greater risk to the fetus), antibody titers cannot predict transmission to the fetus, and treatment of the mother does not prevent neonatal infection.

D) CORRECT:

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists recommend testing all pregnant individuals for HIV (using fourth-generation HIV test), syphilis (using nontreponemal tests, such as VDRL or rapid plasma reagin tests), hepatitis B infection (using HBsAg), and hepatitis C infection (using anti-HCV antibody). All pregnant individuals who are < 25 years or have high risk of infection with Chlamydia and N. gonorrhea should also be screened at the first prenatal visit for Chlamydia and N. gonorrhea infection by PCR of vaginal swabs. All of the tests should be performed at the first prenatal visit, even if any prior test results for these infections were negative.

Pregnant individuals who have not had chickenpox (or have not received the varicella vaccine) and/or those without documentation of seropositivity against rubella should have their anti-varicella and anti-rubella IgG titers measured. Routine prenatal screening for Mycobacterium tuberculosis, cytomegalovirus, herpes simplex virus, Toxoplasma gondii, or parvovirus B19 infections, or routine prenatal serological testing for immunity against these infections, is not recommended.

E) INCORRECT:

Screening for certain infections should be performed during the first trimester at the first prenatal visit so that the patient can be counseled on the risk and prevention of vertical transmission.
questions.hint: Sexually transmitted infections (STIs) can have serious consequences for both the mother and the baby.

questions.text: A 34-year-old primigravid woman comes to the physician for a prenatal visit at 37 weeks' gestation because of worsening back pain for 3 weeks. The pain is worse with extended periods of walking, standing, and sitting. She has not had any changes in bowel movements or urination. Her mother has rheumatoid arthritis. Examination of the back shows bilateral pain along the sacroiliac joint area as a posterior force is applied through the femurs while the knees are flexed. She has difficulty actively raising either leg while the knee is extended. Motor and sensory function are normal bilaterally. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+. Babinski sign is absent. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 37-week gestation. There is no tenderness during abdominal palpation. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Relaxation of the pelvic girdle ligaments

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Spinal cord compression can also manifest with lower back pain. However, other neurologic deficits would also be expected, such as urinary retention, bowel incontinence, weakness, sensation changes, and abnormal reflexes, none of which are seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

Vertebral bone compression fracture can manifest with lower back pain. However, the pain is typically quite severe with point tenderness over the fracture on palpation. In addition, it would be unlikely for this patient to have a vertebral fracture without significant trauma and/or risk factors for osteoporosis (e.g., elderly age, chronic steroid use).

C) INCORRECT:

Although placental abruption can manifest with lower back pain, it is usually also associated with abdominal tenderness, vaginal bleeding, uterine contractions, and fetal distress, none of which are seen here.

D) CORRECT:

While relaxation of the pelvic girdle during pregnancy facilitates the passage of the fetus through the birth canal, it often also causes pelvic girdle pain that may be mistaken for lower back pain. Positive pelvic pain provocation tests (e.g., active straight leg raise) can help differentiate pelvic pain from true lower back pain and guide appropriate treatment. Conservative management with pelvic support (via a brace or girdle), resting in the lateral decubitus position, heat application, and graded exercise may help relieve pelvic girdle pain.

E) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) can affect the hips, which may cause some pain in the sacroiliac area. However, hip involvement in RA typically occurs only in severe or longstanding disease. Although this patient's mother has RA, the patient herself does not have manifestations of this disease, including systemic symptoms (e.g., fatigue, weight loss) or typical joint symptoms (e.g., early morning stiffness, metacarpophalangeal joint or proximal interphalangeal joint pain).

F) INCORRECT:

Although L5 radiculopathy can cause lower back pain, it usually radiates down the lateral leg into the foot. In addition, this patient does not have other typical manifestations of L5 radiculopathy, such as associated weakness on foot dorsiflexion, toe extension, and foot inversion and eversion or a loss of sensation in the webbed spaces between the first and second toes. This patient's normal neurologic exam makes nerve compression an unlikely cause of her symptoms.
questions.hint: Lower back pain is a common symptom during pregnancy.

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravid woman at 16 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a routine prenatal visit. She is asymptomatic and has no history of serious illness. Her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F) and blood pressure is 108/60 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 16-week gestation. A quadruple screening test shows maternal serum α-fetoprotein level of 3 times the median and normal levels of serum β-human chorionic gonadotropin, estriol, and inhibin A. Which of the following is most likely to account for these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

MSAFP levels are not typically increased in cases of isolated fetal hydrocephalus.

B) INCORRECT:

A molar pregnancy typically results in low levels of MSAFP, low levels of unconjugated estriol, increased levels of inhibin A, and extremely high levels of β-hCG.

C) CORRECT:

Increased levels of MSAFP with normal levels of β-hCG, inhibin A, and unconjugated estriol are characteristic of open neural tube defects (e.g., myelomeningocele, anencephaly) and abdominal wall defects (gastroschisis, omphalocele). The diagnosis can be confirmed prenatally in most cases via ultrasound.

Other possible causes of elevated MSAFP include miscalculated gestational age, multiple gestations, fetal death, and placental abnormalities.

D) INCORRECT:

Fetal trisomy 18 would typically result in decreased levels of MSAFP, unconjugated estriol, and β-hCG.

E) INCORRECT:

Fetal trisomy 21 would typically result in decreased levels of MSAFP and unconjugated estriol as well as increased levels of inhibin A and β-hCG.
questions.hint: Isolated elevation of maternal serum α-fetoprotein (MSAFP) levels can be seen in a certain developmental defect associated with folate deficiency.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, comes for a prenatal visit at 33 weeks' gestation. She delivered her first child spontaneously at 38 weeks' gestation; pregnancy was complicated by oligohydramnios. She has no other history of serious illness. Her blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. On pelvic examination, uterine size is found to be smaller than expected for the gestational age. The fetus is in a longitudinal lie, with vertex presentation. The fetal heart rate is 144/min. Ultrasonography shows an estimated fetal weight below the 10th percentile, and decreased amniotic fluid volume. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Reassurance only is not appropriate in a pregnancy with an increased risk of antepartum fetal demise.

B) CORRECT:

Antepartum fetal surveillance with serial tests (e.g., nonstress tests, biophysical profiles) is indicated in pregnancies in which the risk of antepartum fetal demise is increased due to certain maternal (e.g., oligohydramnios, diabetes mellitus, hypertension) and/or fetal conditions (e.g., IUGR, fetal anomalies). In addition to antepartum fetal surveillance, umbilical artery Doppler and ultrasonographic estimation of fetal weight should be performed every 3–4 weeks in the case of IUGR.

In patients at ≥ 32 weeks' gestation with an antepartum fetal assessment showing abnormalities, delivery should be considered.

C) INCORRECT:

Repeat ultrasonography to estimate fetal weight is indicated for all cases of IUGR, but fetal weight estimation should not be performed more frequently than every 2 weeks. This is because fetal weight is indirectly estimated from abdominal circumference, head circumference, fetal femoral length, and biparietal diameter, and these parameters have an error of ± 2 weeks during the 2nd trimester and ± 3 weeks during the 3rd trimester. Ultrasonography to check fetal weight should therefore only be performed every 3–4 weeks.

D) INCORRECT:

In this patient with oligohydramnios, amnioinfusion would only be indicated if evidence of fetal distress due to umbilical cord compression was present.

E) INCORRECT:

In this patient at 33 weeks of gestation, a cesarean delivery would be performed if there was evidence of severe fetal distress. However, oligohydramnios and IUGR are in themselves not indications for cesarean delivery. An elective cesarean section may be performed after 34 weeks if IUGR is accompanied by oligohydramnios.

F) INCORRECT:

Magnesium sulfate is administered to patients with severe preeclampsia, which may result in IUGR and oligohydramnios. This patient, however, does not have gestational hypertension or clinical features of preeclampsia (e.g., severe headache, blurry vision, epigastric pain). In the case of IUGR, magnesium sulfate is also administered for neuroprotection of the fetus if delivery occurs before 32–34 weeks of gestation.
questions.hint: This patient's ultrasound shows intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) and oligohydramnios, both of which are associated with an increased risk of antepartum fetal demise.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 10 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for progressively worsening emesis, nausea, and a 2-kg (4.7-lb) weight loss over the past 2 weeks. The most recent bouts of vomiting occur around 3–4 times a day, and she is stressed that she had to take a sick leave from work the last 2 days. She is currently taking ginger and vitamin B6 with limited relief. Her pulse is 80/min, blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg, and respiratory rate is 13/min. Orthostatic vital signs are within normal limits. The patient is alert and oriented. Her abdomen is soft and nontender. Urinalysis shows no abnormalities. Her hematocrit is 40%. Venous blood gas shows:


pH
7.43 (N = 7.31–7.41)


pO2

42 mm Hg (N = 30–40)


pCO2

54 mm Hg (N = 41–51)


HCO3-

31 mEq/L


SO2

80% (N = 60–85)


In addition to oral fluid resuscitation, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discontinuation of ginger and vitamin B6

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

IV fluid resuscitation would be indicated, if this patient was dehydrated. This woman has stable vital signs and, although her weight loss is concerning, it is more likely attributed to poor solid food intake than due to dehydration. This patient's metabolic alkalosis (elevated HCO3-) is currently compensated (pCO2 slightly elevated) and will further improve with PO fluid replacement if tolerated.

B) INCORRECT:

Administration of supplemental oxygen is not indicated in this patient, since her venous blood gas SO2 (80%) is within the reference range (normal: ∼ 60–85%). In any case, venous blood gas analysis is unsuitable for determining patient oxygenation status. The gold standard is arterial blood gas analysis. The SO2 in arterial blood is usually about 20% higher than in venous blood since arterial blood becomes oxygenated in the lungs.

C) INCORRECT:

Scheduled meal times every one to two hours with small amounts of food may help to improve symptoms, since a very full or empty stomach can trigger nausea. However, such dietary changes alone will most likely not be successful in this patient with progressively worsening emesis.

D) INCORRECT:

Psychological responses to stress may exacerbate nausea and vomiting. Although counseling and close monitoring may be helpful, they are insufficient for relieving this patient's immediate symptoms. In rare cases, hyperemesis gravidarum is due to conditions that require psychological counseling, such as functional neurological symptom disorder, somatization disorder, or depression.

E) INCORRECT:

Bismuth subsalicylate is used to treat patients with nausea and emesis. However, this medication is contraindicated during pregnancy because it can cross the placenta and may adversely affect the fetus. Antacids, preferably containing aluminum or calcium, can be used as adjunctive therapy in pregnant women with acid reflux.

F) INCORRECT:

Metoclopramide is used in the treatment of nausea and vomiting of pregnancy. However, metoclopramide is only indicated if other treatment options have been unsuccessful or if patients have refractory symptoms despite initial combination therapy.

G) INCORRECT:

Discontinuation of ginger and vitamin B6 is not recommended since both are safe substances with antiemetic properties.

H) CORRECT:

If vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) alone does not improve nausea and vomiting of pregnancy, doxylamine should be administered. Dietary changes (e.g., cutting out spicy, high-fat, and/or acidic foods) and avoidance of triggers (e.g., poorly ventilated rooms, loud noises, strong and/or unpleasant odors) may also improve nausea. If treatment with pyridoxine and doxylamine is unsuccessful, antiemetics such as dimenhydrinate, diphenhydramine, or promethazine can be administered.

In patients with severe dehydration and metabolic alkalosis (due to frequent vomiting), IV rehydration with electrolyte supplementation should be initiated. Chlorpromazine and methylprednisolone should be used with caution and only in patients who have not responded to other treatments.
questions.hint: This patient's venous blood gas results show a slightly elevated partial pressure of carbon dioxide and bicarbonate but an otherwise normal partial pressure of oxygen and oxygen saturation. Moreover, she has no clinical signs of dehydration (e.g., severe weight loss, abnormal orthostatic vital signs). These findings indicate uncomplicated nausea and vomiting of pregnancy.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 36 weeks' gestation is brought to the emergency department after an episode of dizziness and vomiting followed by loss of consciousness lasting 1 minute. She reports that her symptoms started after lying down on her back to rest, as she felt tired during yoga class. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated. On arrival, she is diaphoretic and pale. Her pulse is 115/min and blood pressure is 90/58 mm Hg. On examination, the patient is lying in the supine position with a fundal height of 36 cm. There is a prolonged fetal heart rate deceleration to 80/min. Which of the following is the most appropriate action to reverse this patient's symptoms in the future?

choices.text: Lying in the supine position and elevating legs
Gentle compression with an abdominal binder
Lying in the left lateral decubitus position

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Muller maneuver causes intrathoracic pressure to become more negative, thereby improving venous return to the heart. Although it could be beneficial for this patient, this maneuver would not resolve the cause of her symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Elevating the legs while lying in the supine position increases venous return to the heart. Although it could be beneficial for this patient, this maneuver would not resolve the cause of her symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Gentle compression with an abdominal binder can be used in pregnant patients with back problems. However, abdominal compression can decrease venous return to the heart, which could worsen this patient's symptoms.

D) CORRECT:

The left lateral decubitus position is generally recommended for pregnant women when lying down, especially in the third trimester, because this position shifts the uterus away from and thus avoids compression of the inferior vena cava. Compression of the inferior vena cava is the cause of supine hypotensive syndrome, which results in compromised venous return and leads to decreased cardiac output, fetal hypoxia, and prolonged decelerations on cardiotocography, as seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Hand grip maneuver increases systemic vascular resistance and afterload. This maneuver is used for better evaluation of heart murmurs (e.g., mitral regurgitation, aortic regurgitation, VSD). It would not, however, resolve the cause of this patient's symptoms.

F) INCORRECT:

Valsalva maneuver increases intrathoracic pressure, thereby decreasing venous return to the heart. This maneuver could worsen this patient's symptoms.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms are consistent with supine hypotensive syndrome, which frequently occurs due to compression of the inferior vena cava associated with the anatomical changes involved in pregnancy.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 12 weeks' gestation comes to her obstetrician for a prenatal visit. Screening tests in the first trimester showed a decreased level of pregnancy-associated plasma protein and an increased level of β-human chorionic gonadotropin. A genetic disorder is suspected. Which of the following results from an additional diagnostic test is most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis at this time?

choices.text: Decreased inhibin A in maternal serum

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased (not decreased!) fetal nuchal translucency, which can be measured via ultrasonography in the first-trimester combined screening, would be consistent with Down syndrome. Moreover, a diagnostic test rather than a second screening test is necessary to confirm the diagnosis at this time.

B) CORRECT:

Chorionic villus sampling (CVS) is the diagnostic test of choice at 10–13 weeks' gestation to confirm suspected Down syndrome, given her abnormal first-trimester combined screening results. An extra copy of chromosome 21 in placental tissue confirms this diagnosis. CVS is invasive and carries a 2–3% risk of miscarriage.

First-trimester combined screening also includes sonographic measurement of nuchal translucency. Thickening of the nuchal fold (> 95th percentile) is a nonspecific sign of fetal abnormality (chromosomal aberrations, malformations) and would also be expected in this fetus with suspected Down syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Maternal free estriol levels are measured as part of the quadruple screening, which is conducted between 15–22 weeks' gestation. Decreased free estriol levels are consistent with several fetal genetic anomalies, including trisomy 21 and trisomy 18. This patient's abnormal first trimester-combined screening results are suggestive of trisomy 21. Although maternal estriol levels are likely decreased in this patient, the quadruple screening test would not provide further confirmation at 12 weeks' gestation. A confirmatory test is required instead.

D) INCORRECT:

Triploidy describes the presence of three sets of chromosomes. Like trisomy, triploidy is a type of chromosomal aberration that can be detected during prenatal screening. This patient's first-trimester screening results are suggestive of trisomy 21, rather than a triploidy. In addition, although amniocentesis is a diagnostic test used to confirm the diagnosis of chromosomal aberrations during pregnancy, it is performed in the second trimester between 15–20 weeks' gestation and would not be appropriate in this patient at 12 weeks' gestation.

E) INCORRECT:

Inhibin A levels in maternal serum are typically measured as part of the quadruple screening in the second trimester (specifically between 15–22 weeks' gestation). However, inhibin A levels cannot confirm the presence of a chromosomal aberration. Furthermore, an increased rather than a decreased inhibin A level is consistent with trisomy 21.
questions.hint: This patient's first-trimester combined screening results show decreased levels of PAPP-A and increased levels of β-hCG, which suggests Down syndrome.

questions.text: A 3500-g (7 lb 11 oz) healthy female newborn is delivered at 38 weeks' gestation. Chorionic villus sampling (CVS) in the first trimester showed a trisomy of chromosome 21 but the pregnancy was otherwise uncomplicated. Physical examination of the newborn is normal.
