Chromosomal analysis at birth shows a 46, XX karyotype. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the prenatal chromosomal abnormality?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Locus heterogeneity occurs when mutations in genes at different chromosomal loci cause the same phenotype. This means that two individuals with the same disease might have a different genotype; however, this would not cause a genetic discrepancy within an individual's tissue and does not explain the normal phenotype of the newborn.

B) INCORRECT:

Maternal uniparental disomy is a genetic anomaly in which the individual inherits two of the same chromosomes from one parent and none from the other. Uniparental disomy does not lead to polysomy and therefore would not explain the presence of trisomy 21 in the placental tissue.

C) INCORRECT:

Trisomy 21 is an example of phenotypic pleiotropy, in which one gene contributes to different phenotypic effects. Affected patients may display several developmental deformities, such as a palmar crease, upward slanting palpebral fissure, and cardiac defects. However, pleiotropy would not explain this patient's normal phenotype or the discrepancy between her placental and actual genotype.

D) INCORRECT:

Incomplete penetrance is the phenomenon by which not all individuals with a mutant genotype express the corresponding phenotype. However, trisomy 21 is typically not associated with incomplete penetrance. Furthermore, it would not explain the chromosomal discordance between the chorionic villus sample and the newborn tissue.

E) INCORRECT:

Maternal heteroplasmy refers to the presence of heterogeneous mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) in an individual. Because all mitochondria are inherited from the mother, mitochondrial diseases that develop in utero are a result of unequal distribution of normal and mutated mtDNA molecules during mitosis. Thus, genetic discrepancies in a patient can be observed depending on which cells are sampled. However, trisomy 21 is a polysomy that affects the nuclear genome, not the mitochondrial genome.
Image Description:

Following de novo mutations in mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA), cells have both mutated and normal mitochondria, which is known as heteroplasmy. When there is heteroplasmy in the parental cell (P), levels of heteroplasmy can increase, decrease, or stay the same in subsequent filial generations (F1, F2), resulting in variable disease expression. Severity often correlates with the proportion of mutated mtDNA. In some conditions, the disease phenotype is only expressed once the proportion of mutated mtDNA is above a certain threshold.

F) INCORRECT:

Variable expressivity is the mechanism by which mutations result in varying degrees of phenotypic severity. Patients with trisomy 21 often have varying degrees of clinical severity despite having the same genetic anomaly. However, variable expressivity does not explain the genetic discordance between the newborn and placental tissue.

G) CORRECT:

In CVS, a sample from the placenta is taken to test for chromosomal abnormalities, rather than direct fetal tissue. In rare cases, there is a discrepancy between the sampled placental genotype and that of the fetus (mosaicism of the placenta). In confined placental mosaicism, the CVS may show an abnormal genotype but the fetus has a normal genotype, as seen here.
questions.hint: This genetic phenomenon occurs in about 1–2% of all pregnancies in which chorionic villus sampling (CVS) is performed.

questions.text: A previously healthy 29-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 35 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a routine prenatal visit. Current medications include folic acid and a multivitamin. A rectovaginal swab culture grows bacitracin-resistant colonies of gram-positive cocci with surrounding areas of clear hemolysis. Which of the following is the most appropriate intervention to decrease vertical transmission of this organism?

choices.text: Schedule delivery of the fetus via C-section

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Scheduling delivery of the fetus via C-section would not be appropriate for this patient. Colonization with GBS or active infection (e.g., chorioamnionitis) is not a routine indication for C-section. Cesarean deliveries are reserved for patients with standard obstetric indications (e.g., insufficient maternal contractions, fetal malposition, cephalopelvic disproportion) or severe infections that present along with fetal distress.

B) INCORRECT:

Benzathine penicillin G is used in the treatment of syphilis and infection with Streptococcus pyogenes (which is sensitive to bacitracin, unlike the organism cultured in this patient). While GBS infection can also be treated with penicillin G, administration of the antibiotic at this time would not be appropriate because it does not eliminate the risk of recolonization at the time of delivery.

C) INCORRECT:

Abstaining from breastfeeding due to a group B streptococcal (GBS) infection would not be appropriate in this patient. GBS can be passed to the neonate during delivery but not through breast milk. Reasons to permanently abstain from breastfeeding include maternal infections with retroviruses (e.g., HIV and human T-cell lymphotropic virus) or ebola virus, or classic galactosemia in the infant. Indications for temporarily abstaining include active herpes infection and concomitant use of toxic medications (e.g., tetracyclines).

D) CORRECT:

Ampicillin (or penicillin G) is administered in the intrapartum period as prophylaxis for neonatal GBS disease. Maternal GBS colonization is a major risk factor for early-onset neonatal infection and sepsis. Prenatal screening for GBS colonization (culture of vaginal and rectal swabs) is indicated in all pregnant women from 36+0 to 37+6 weeks' gestation and intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis is indicated in all women with a positive screening. It is also indicated in women with GBS bacteriuria occurring any time during pregnancy and in those who have previously given birth to a newborn with GBS infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Intravenous immune globulin (IVIG) is administered postpartum as prophylaxis in several scenarios, e.g., in neonates exposed to measles or in the case of Rh incompatibility. IVIG is not indicated in patients with a swab that is positive for group B streptococcus (GBS).
questions.hint: This patient's swab culture is positive for group B streptococcus (GBS), which is a bacitracin-resistant, β-hemolytic, gram-positive coccus.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 17 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a routine prenatal examination. Serum studies at 16 weeks' gestation showed an abnormally elevated alpha-fetoprotein level and normal beta-human chorionic gonadotropin and estriol levels. After genetic counseling, the patient decides to continue with the pregnancy without any diagnostic testing. The remainder of her pregnancy is uncomplicated and she delivers a boy at 38 weeks' gestation. Analysis of the infant's leukocytes shows a 46, XY karyotype. Which of the following is the most likely cause for the abnormal triple test results?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Robertsonian translocation accounts for a minority of cases of Down syndrome, Patau syndrome, and Edwards syndrome and would be associated with a normal chromosomal number, as seen here. However, Down syndrome, Patau syndrome, and Edwards syndrome would usually result in decreased levels of AFP and estriol in maternal serum, and abnormal findings on first-trimester ultrasonography (e.g., increased nuchal translucency). The constellation of increased MSAFP, normal serum β-hCG and estriol, and normal first-trimester ultrasound has a different explanation.

B) CORRECT:

Incorrect estimation of the gestational age is the most common cause of abnormal MSAFP levels; in this case, the patient most likely underestimated the duration of her pregnancy. As a result, the MSAFP value was compared to the standardized mean for a 17-week-old fetus when, in actuality, the fetus was further along in development. Because AFP is synthesized by the fetal yolk sac, liver, and gastrointestinal tract, its concentration increases throughout pregnancy as the fetus grows. Thus, an inaccurate gestational age can cause the maternal serum level to appear abnormally low or high. Measurement of MSAFP is often combined with fetal ultrasound to ensure that the blood test is interpreted based on the correct gestational age.

C) INCORRECT:

Congenital umbilical hernia is associated with normal MSAFP levels. It is caused by incomplete closure of the abdominal ring and commonly manifests as an asymptomatic, reducible, skin-covered bulge at the umbilicus. It is distinct from gastroschisis and omphalocele, both of which are abdominal wall defects that cause exposure and herniation of abdominal viscera as well as elevated MSAFP levels.

D) INCORRECT:

Although spina bifida (and other open neural tube defects) manifests with elevated MSAFP levels, spina bifida occulta is associated with a normal MSAFP. Because spina bifida occulta does not result in communication between the fetal tissue and the amniotic fluid, AFP cannot leak into the amnion. Neonates with this condition classically present with a tuft of hair or skin dimple at the level of the defect in the lumbar spine.

E) INCORRECT:

Congenital hypothyroidism due to thyroid dysgenesis is associated with increased MSAFP but maternal hypothyroidism is not associated with elevated MSAFP.

F) INCORRECT:

Gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD) would not result in a viable fetus. Moreover, GTD would have resulted in elevated serum β-hCG, decreased or normal MSAFP, and an intrauterine mass with multiple hypoechoic foci on ultrasonography. The constellation of normal serum β-hCG, increased MSAFP, normal first-trimester ultrasound, and viable term pregnancy has a different explanation.
questions.hint: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is produced by the fetus and can be measured in maternal serum (MSAFP), which continuously rises during the second trimester. While elevated MSAFP levels are associated with certain developmental defects that create pathological communications between the fetus and the amnion (e.g., abdominal wall defects, open neural tube defects), other benign factors may also lead to abnormal test results.

questions.text: A 17-year-old primigravid girl at 30 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a routine prenatal visit. She reports some tiredness but has otherwise been well. She has attended all of her prenatal screening appointments so far, which showed no abnormalities. Immunizations are up-to-date. She takes prenatal supplements. She has no history of serious illness and takes no other medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a fundal height consistent with a 30-week gestation. Just before leaving the consulting room, she mentions that she does not intend to come for any more prenatal appointments because she lives too far away. The patient should be counseled that refusing further prenatal screening increases the risk of which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Myelomeningocele is a type of neural tube defect (NTD), which is the most common congenital malformation of the central nervous system. Prenatal screening for NTDs includes measurement of maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein at 16–18 weeks' gestation or ultrasound examination between 18–20 weeks' gestation. Since this patient is at 30 weeks of gestation and all of her previous prenatal visits were normal, discontinuing prenatal checkups now will not increase the risk of myelomeningocele.

B) INCORRECT:

Fetal macrosomia can result from maternal gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM). All pregnant women are initially screened for GDM with an oral glucose challenge test between 24–28 weeks of gestation. Since this patient is currently at 30 weeks' gestation and all of her previous prenatal visits were normal, the likelihood of her having GDM is very low. Therefore, discontinuing further prenatal care is unlikely to increase the risk of macrosomia in this fetus.

C) INCORRECT:

Congenital rubella syndrome is caused by the transplacental transfer of the rubella virus from an infected mother to her fetus. All pregnant women (unless there is evidence of immunity) are screened for rubella antibodies at the initial prenatal visit. Since this patient's immunizations are up to date and all of her previous prenatal visits showed no abnormalities, discontinuing further prenatal visits after 30 weeks of gestation is unlikely to increase the risk of congenital rubella infection.

D) CORRECT:

Neonatal sepsis can result from infection with Group B streptococcus (GBS), which colonizes the maternal genital tract in 15–40% of pregnant women. Transmission to the fetus can occur after the rupture of membranes or during labor (i.e., passage through the birth canal). Therefore, prenatal screening for GBS is performed in all pregnant women between 36 0/7 and 37 6/7 weeks of gestation via culture and gram staining of vaginal and rectal swabs. If this patient refuses further prenatal screening after 30 weeks' gestation, she will not be screened for GBS, thus increasing her child's risk of neonatal sepsis. Moreover, GBS can lead to urinary tract infections, cystitis, pyelonephritis, and chorioamnionitis during pregnancy, all of which can be avoided by screening and treatment. Patients with a positive screening test for GBS should receive intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis with IV penicillin G or ampicillin.

E) INCORRECT:

Hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn (HDFN) most commonly results from a Rhesus (Rh) or ABO incompatibility between the mother and fetus. Rh incompatibility is more likely to cause severe symptoms in the newborn. Therefore, screening Rh-negative mothers for anti-D antibodies takes place at the initial prenatal visit with further anti-D antibody testing at 28 weeks' gestation. Since this patient is already at 30 weeks of gestation and all of her previous prenatal visits showed no abnormalities, discontinuing prenatal visits at this point would not increase the risk of HDFN.
questions.hint: Think about the prenatal screening tests that women usually undergo after 30 weeks' gestation.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 24 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated and she feels well. Her first child was born via cesarean delivery because of fetal macrosomia. The patient has no history of serious illness. Her current medications include folic acid and a prenatal vitamin. She is 166 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 90 kg (198 lb); her prepregnancy BMI was 30 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 118/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a fundal height of 28 cm. Transvaginal ultrasound shows an amniotic fluid index of 27 cm and no evidence of fetal anomalies. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Doppler ultrasonography of the fetal arteries can be used to diagnose hemolytic disease of the fetus, which can cause hydrops fetalis and is associated with polyhydramnios. However, hydrops fetalis is associated with ultrasound findings of ascites, pleural effusions, pericardial effusions, and/or skin edema, none of which are present in this patient's ultrasound. A different test should be performed to identify the etiology of polyhydramnios in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and follow-up during this patient's next routine prenatal visit in 4 weeks would be indicated if her examination at this time showed no abnormalities. This patient's transvaginal ultrasound findings are consistent with polyhydramnios, which requires further evaluation and management.

C) CORRECT:

The two most common identifiable causes of polyhydramnios are fetal abnormalities and gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM). Given the absence of any fetal abnormalities on transvaginal ultrasonography and the presence of several risk factors for GDM (e.g., obesity, fetal macrosomia during a previous pregnancy), this patient's polyhydramnios is most likely caused by GDM. Therefore, a GDM screening test is recommended at this time.

The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists recommends GDM screening in all pregnant patients between 24–28 weeks' gestation; early screening (prior to 24 weeks) is recommended in women with risk factors for GDM. GDM can be diagnosed using a one- or two-step oral glucose challenge test.

D) INCORRECT:

Cell-free fetal DNA testing is typically used for the prenatal screening of common fetal aneuploidies (e.g., trisomy 21, trisomy 18), which can be associated with polyhydramnios. However, this patient's ultrasound at 24 weeks' gestation shows no fetal abnormalities, so fetal aneuploidies are unlikely. A different test should be performed to identify the etiology of polyhydramnios in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Amniocentesis can be used to evaluate for fetal genetic abnormalities, hemolytic anemia, and infection, all of which can be associated with polyhydramnios. This patient's transvaginal ultrasound shows no fetal abnormalities, hydrops fetalis, or signs of fetal distress, so these diagnoses are unlikely. A different test should be performed to identify the etiology of polyhydramnios in this patient.
questions.hint: A large uterine size for gestational age (i.e., fundal height (in cm) that exceeds the gestational age (in weeks) between 24 and 36 weeks' gestation) and an amniotic fluid index (AFI) ≥ 24 cm indicate polyhydramnios.

questions.text: A 29-year-old primigravid woman at 36 weeks' gestation comes for a prenatal visit. She reports some tiredness but has otherwise been well. She was successfully treated with fosfomycin for asymptomatic group B Streptococcus bacteriuria in the first trimester. She has since moved to a different state and has not attended any further routine prenatal visits. Last year, while she was being treated with amoxicillin for bacterial sinusitis, she developed a rash on her chest that resolved spontaneously. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable and her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a uterus that is consistent in size with a 36-week gestation. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation?

choices.text: Collection of rectovaginal swab for culture
Administration of penicillin to the newborn after delivery

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's history of asymptomatic GBS bacteriuria in the first trimester warrants intrapartum GBS prophylaxis regardless of GBS culture results. Cefazolin is the antibiotic of choice for neonatal GBS prophylaxis in women who have a history of mild penicillin allergy. Patients with a high risk for anaphylaxis (e.g., a history of immediate flushing, angioedema, respiratory distress after penicillin intake) require intrapartum clindamycin, or vancomycin if GBS is resistant to clindamycin. If allergy status is unclear, penicillin skin testing should be performed prior to labor.

B) INCORRECT:

Intrapartum penicillin is indicated for intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis in patients with GBS colonization who do not have a history of anaphylactic reaction to penicillin. This patient has a history of a mild reaction to amoxicillin and therefore requires a different approach.

C) INCORRECT:

A rectovaginal swab for GBS culture is generally indicated between 36+0–37+6 weeks' gestation to determine GBS status and whether intrapartum prophylactic antibiotics are necessary to prevent neonatal GBS infection. However, in patients who have developed GBS bacteriuria at any point during the current pregnancy and in patients with a history of previous delivery of a newborn with GBS infection, intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis is indicated without prior GBS culture.

D) INCORRECT:

Administration of penicillin after delivery is indicated for all neonates with confirmed GBS infection. Vaginally delivered neonates of women with GBS colonization have a higher risk of developing early onset GBS infection. However, preventive administration of antibiotics to the neonate is not recommended.

E) INCORRECT:

A urine culture is indicated in all pregnant patients, typically at 12–16 weeks' gestation, to screen for asymptomatic bacteriuria, which is associated with adverse pregnancy outcomes (e.g., preterm labor, low birth weight). Repeat urine culture is also required around one week after treatment to ensure that the therapy has been effective. However, a urine culture in this patient has already confirmed asymptomatic GBS bacteriuria, which was successfully treated. A different intervention is indicated at this time.
questions.hint: Indications for intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis include positive screening culture for group B Streptococcus (GBS), previous delivery of a newborn with GBS infection, and GBS bacteriuria at any time during pregnancy.

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: No further management is indicated at this time
Perform an oral glucose tolerance test

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increasing iron supplementation can be necessary for iron deficiency anemia (IDA). This patient has an Hb of 11.5 g/dL, which is abnormal using regular cutoff values. However, diagnostic Hb levels for anemia during pregnancy should be used when assessing for IDA as there is an expected physiological decrease in hemoglobin during pregnancy due to increased plasma volume (i.e., dilutional anemia). Iron deficiency anemia in pregnancy is defined by an Hb < 11 g/dL in the first trimester. Increasing this patient's iron supplement is therefore not indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient has risk factors for GDM and requires further management.

C) INCORRECT:

Screening for thrombophilia is recommended in pregnant individuals at high risk of thrombophilic events (e.g., a history of unexplained thrombosis, recurrent miscarriage, or a strong family history of thrombotic events). However, routine screening is not recommended after a single miscarriage.

D) INCORRECT:

Anti-D immunoglobulin prevents hemolytic disease of the newborn in pregnancies of Rhesus (Rh)-negative individuals with Rhesus (Rh)-positive fetuses. It is indicated for unsensitized Rh-negative pregnant individuals in any potentially sensitizing event (e.g., invasive prenatal diagnostic tests, miscarriage) or as a prophylactic starting at 28 weeks' gestation. However, this patient is Rh positive.

E) CORRECT:

Screening for GDM with an oral glucose tolerance test is typically performed toward the end of the second trimester, between 24 and 28 weeks' gestation. However, in patients with risk factors for GDM, earlier screening at the initial prenatal visit is recommended. If the initial screening is negative, oral glucose testing should be repeated with the recommended second-trimester laboratory studies.

Other risk factors for GDM include gestational diabetes during a previous pregnancy, recurrent pregnancy loss, and general risk factors for type 2 diabetes mellitus (e.g., polycystic ovary syndrome).
questions.hint: This patient has obesity, a prior pregnancy with fetal macrosomia, and a first-degree relative with type 2 diabetes, all of which are risk factors for gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM).

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman with obesity reports that she had a positive home pregnancy test. Her last menstrual period was 7 weeks ago. She describes having morning sickness, with nausea and vomiting, and is taking herbal remedies that have not helped. She weighed 113 kg before pregnancy and has recently lost 3 kg.
Her laboratory results — including electrolyte and amylase levels, thyroid-stimulating hormone levels, liver-function studies, and urinalysis — are all within normal limits.
Which one of the following management recommendations is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Admit her to the hospital for intravenous hydration
Initiate treatment with a histamine-2-receptor antagonist
Recommend that she include some fat content with each meal
Recommend that she eat frequent, small, bland meals

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous hydration with multivitamins (including thiamine) and antiemetic agents is indicated as first-line treatment for women with hyperemesis gravidarum, which is characterized by persistent nausea and vomiting associated with ketosis and weight loss (>5% of prepregnancy weight).

B) INCORRECT:

Pharmacologic options for treating hyperemesis gravidarum include vitamin B6, doxylamine (an antihistamine), and metoclopramide. A histamine-2-receptor antagonist would not be effective.

C) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoid therapy is reserved for the most refractory cases of hyperemesis gravidarum, which is characterized by persistent nausea and vomiting associated with ketosis and weight loss (>5% of prepregnancy weight).

D) INCORRECT:

Behavioral and dietary modifications are the first-line therapy for nausea and vomiting in early pregnancy. High-fat meals are not known to be effective for nausea and vomiting in early pregnancy.

E) CORRECT:

Behavioral and dietary modifications are the first-line therapy for nausea and vomiting in early pregnancy. Recommendations include avoiding exposure to triggers for nausea (common ones include fatty or spicy foods and iron tablets), eating small amounts of food several times a day, drinking fluids between meals, and consuming foods that are bland, dry, and high in protein.

Nausea and vomiting that persist despite these behavioral and dietary modifications and that are associated with ketosis and weight loss (>5% of prepregnancy weight) are considered hyperemesis gravidarum. This condition can cause volume depletion, nutritional deficiencies, liver-function abnormalities, electrolyte and acid-base disturbances, and even death. The reported incidence is 0.3% to 1.0%.

Key learning point: Nausea and vomiting in early pregnancy with weight loss of less than 5% and no abnormal laboratory findings is most likely to be attributable to morning sickness.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old primigravida woman who is at 40 weeks and 0 days’ gestation, according to her last menstrual period and 9-week dating ultrasound, presents for follow-up. She has had a healthy, uncomplicated pregnancy and is negative for group B streptococcus by rectovaginal swab culture.
Her blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg. Her fundal height is 40 cm. She reports regular active fetal movements; Leopold maneuvers and office ultrasound confirm that the baby is in vertex presentation. The cervix is closed, 3 cm long, and posterior.
The patient would prefer to go into spontaneous labor and avoid an induction of labor if possible.
What is the most appropriate next step in this patient's care?

choices.text: Begin daily fetal kick counts now
Begin Doppler ultrasonography of the umbilical artery twice weekly at 41 weeks and 0 days' gestation
Begin twice-weekly antepartum assessment at 41 weeks and 0 days' gestation, with either biophysical profile or a modified biophysical profile
Obtain an ultrasound to assess fetal growth

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fetal movement decreases in response to hypoxemia, making fetal kick counts a potential method of monitoring fetal well-being. However, existing evidence does not support any specific fetal-movement threshold below which fetal risk increases, and routine fetal kick counting to prevent stillbirth is not recommended.

B) INCORRECT:

Doppler ultrasonography of the umbilical artery has shown a benefit only in pregnancies complicated by intrauterine growth restriction.

C) CORRECT:

A post-term pregnancy is one that has extended beyond 42 weeks’ gestation, and a late-term pregnancy is one that has reached between 41 weeks and 0 days and 41 weeks and 6 days. The risk for antepartum fetal demise increases after 40 weeks’ gestation, and a late-term or postterm pregnancy is a universally accepted indication for fetal surveillance.

The ideal antepartum surveillance strategy has not been defined. Consensus opinion suggests twice-weekly monitoring after 41 weeks' gestation with either a biophysical profile or a modified biophysical profile (nonstress testing with an amniotic fluid index).

Induction of labor is indicated for nonreassuring fetal surveillance but may also be considered earlier. In a large randomized controlled trial conducted among low-risk nulliparous women, those assigned to undergo induction of labor after 39 weeks had a lower rate of cesarean delivery than those assigned to expectant management; the two groups had similar rates of neonatal complications. Women should be counseled about the risks and benefits of labor induction. Induction can be considered after 39 weeks, and most providers recommend labor induction after 41 weeks. However, for patients who prefer to await spontaneous labor, initiating antepartum surveillance in the late term with induction of labor after 42 weeks is also a reasonable strategy.

Key learning point: The most appropriate fetal surveillance strategy for a healthy pregnant woman who has not delivered by 40 weeks’ gestation is twice-weekly antepartum assessment, starting at 41 weeks' gestation, with biophysical profile testing or modified biophysical profile testing.

D) INCORRECT:

Routine ultrasonography to assess for fetal growth is not indicated for low-risk late-term or postterm pregnancy in the absence of other findings such as a size-date discrepancy on clinical examination.

E) INCORRECT:

Consensus opinion suggests twice-weekly monitoring after 41 weeks' gestation with either a biophysical profile or a modified biophysical profile (nonstress testing with an amniotic fluid index).

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman who has never been pregnant and has no significant medical history presents for a preconception appointment. She reached menarche at age 14; her menstrual period occurs every 29 days and lasts for 3 to 4 days. She is in a monogamous relationship, in which she and her partner consistently use condoms and spermicide. She does not currently use oral contraceptive pills.
She has no history of sexually transmitted infections and received all of her childhood vaccinations. Her family history is significant for hypertension in her mother and cirrhosis secondary to alcohol use disorder in her father; her siblings are healthy. She does not smoke tobacco or use illicit drugs. She consumes one glass of wine per month but plans to stop during her pregnancy. She currently works as a second-grade teacher; maternity leave is offered through her employer.
She is 167 cm tall and weighs 86 kg (BMI, 30.8). Her temperature is 37.0°C, her blood pressure is 124/76 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 75 beats per minute; she breathes comfortably on room air. Overall, her physical examination is unremarkable except for a soft (grade 1/6) systolic flow murmur present at the apex without radiation.
In addition to obtaining preconception laboratory testing and recommending folic acid supplementation, which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Counsel the patient about weight loss
Refer the patient to a genetic counselor
Counsel the patient about birth control

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound is not typically obtained at a preconception visit. It is used at later visits to visualize the baby, detect the baby’s heartbeat, and verify the due date.

B) CORRECT:

During a preconception visit, a full history should be elicited from the patient, including the patient’s medical history, family history, surgical history, current medications, prior pregnancies, and social activities. A physical examination, including a pelvic examination, should be completed, and laboratory testing is typically conducted, including a complete blood count, rubella titer, varicella titer, hepatitis B/C virus panel, screening for HIV and other sexually transmitted infections, and screening for pregestational diabetes (typically a fasting glucose or a glycated hemoglobin measurement). Based on the results of the evaluation, the clinician can provide targeted counseling and interventions to optimize the chances of a successful pregnancy and to reduce risk factors for pregnancy complications.

For this patient, whose BMI falls into the obesity category, the most appropriate next step is to provide counseling about weight loss. Women with obesity can have higher rates of infertility, longer time to conception, and increased risk for pregnancy complications. They should therefore be counseled to lose weight before pregnancy, although the amount of weight loss needed has not been determined. In the setting of seeking pregnancy, weight loss is typically achieved by promoting lifelong lifestyle changes such as mild-to-moderate caloric restriction and exercise, which can induce a weight loss of 3% to 7% over 4 to 6 months. Weight loss medications have not been studied in women who are trying to conceive and are therefore not used in this setting. Similarly, surgical weight-loss procedures are not recommended in women who are actively trying to conceive, as current recommendations call for delaying pregnancy for 12 to 18 months after such procedures.

Key learning point: Weight-loss counseling is indicated for women with obesity who are planning a pregnancy.

C) INCORRECT:

Although the patient does have a murmur on examination, the features of the murmur indicate that it is a benign flow murmur, a common nonpathologic finding that does not warrant echocardiographic evaluation.

D) INCORRECT:

Referral to a genetic counselor is not always indicated but may be useful in patients who have a history of hereditary conditions such as sickle cell anemia, cystic fibrosis, or Down syndrome. Other indications for preconception genetic counseling include advanced maternal age, history of infertility, and history of environmental exposures. This patient does not meet any of these criteria; therefore, genetic referral is not needed.

E) INCORRECT:

Given that this patient is completing a preconception appointment, birth control counseling is not indicated; she is also already using adequate birth control.

questions.text:
A full-term male infant born via spontaneous vaginal delivery to a 32-year-old gravida 2, para 2 mother is evaluated immediately after birth. Membranes were ruptured at the time of delivery, and the infant’s Apgar scores were 7 at one minute and 9 at five minutes.
The mother tested positive for group B streptococcus vaginal colonization during her third trimester and was treated with one dose of penicillin 30 minutes before delivery. She had no fever or uterine fundal tenderness during delivery or the immediate postpartum period.
The infant has mild acral cyanosis but otherwise appears well and has a normal newborn examination.
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this infant?

choices.text: Obtain a complete blood count and blood culture, and treat empirically with ampicillin and gentamicin
Obtain a blood culture, and defer antibiotic treatment unless cultures show evidence of bacteremia
Obtain a chest radiograph, and provide empiric treatment with ampicillin and gentamicin
Administer a dose of intramuscular penicillin

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Group B streptococcus (GBS or Streptococcus agalactiae) is a gram-positive bacterium that colonizes up to 40% of pregnant women. It is an important cause of neonatal disease when transmitted vertically to an infant during delivery. Early-onset disease occurs in the first week of life and typically manifests as sepsis, pneumonia, or meningitis. Late-onset disease occurs after the first week of life and typically manifests as sepsis or meningitis; on rare occasions, it manifests as bone or soft-tissue infection.

All women should undergo culture-based screening for vaginal and rectal GBS colonization at 35 to 37 weeks’ gestation. Those who test positive should receive intravenous penicillin every 4 hours from the onset of labor or membrane rupture until delivery. In the setting of penicillin allergy, clindamycin, vancomycin, or cefazolin may be used; however, clindamycin or vancomycin alone is not considered adequate intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis. Susceptibility testing should be done if clindamycin is used for prophylaxis. In the setting of maternal GBS bacteriuria during the current pregnancy or maternal history of a prior infant with invasive GBS infection, women do not require GBS screening cultures and should be treated with intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis.

A minimum of 4 hours of intrapartum antibiotics is considered adequate prophylaxis. In cases where a GBS-positive mother receives inadequate prophylaxis and the infant appears well, the next step depends on the gestational age of the infant, highest maternal antepartum temperature, timing of membrane rupture, type and duration of maternal intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis, and clinical examination of the infant after birth. Many centers are moving toward the use of multivariate risk assessment (e.g., Neonatal Early-Onset Sepsis Calculator) in an effort to more accurately predict an infant’s risk for early-onset sepsis and reduce unnecessary neonatal antibiotic administration when clinically appropriate.

Key learning point: For a well-appearing, full-term neonate born via spontaneous vaginal delivery to a mother who had group B streptococcus vaginal colonization, received inadequate intrapartum antibiotics, and did not have prolonged rupture of membranes, the most appropriate management approach is 48 hours of observation.

B) INCORRECT:

Empiric antibiotic coverage and further workup — including complete blood count, blood culture, lumbar puncture, and chest radiograph — would potentially be indicated if the infant had additional risk factors or was showing clinical signs or symptoms concerning for early-onset sepsis.

C) INCORRECT:

Empiric antibiotic coverage and further workup — including complete blood count, blood culture, lumbar puncture, and chest radiograph — would potentially be indicated if the infant had additional risk factors or was showing clinical signs or symptoms concerning for early-onset sepsis.

D) INCORRECT:

Empiric antibiotic coverage and further workup — including complete blood count, blood culture, lumbar puncture, and chest radiograph — would potentially be indicated if the infant had additional risk factors or was showing clinical signs or symptoms concerning for early-onset sepsis.

E) INCORRECT:

Empiric antibiotic coverage would potentially be indicated if the infant had additional risk factors or was showing clinical signs or symptoms concerning for early-onset sepsis.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old gravida 5, para 3 woman with a history of fibroids does not know when her last menstrual period was. Findings of a bimanual examination are consistent with a pregnancy of 10 weeks’ gestation.
An in-clinic ultrasound reveals a small embryonic pole (<5 mm long) and a yolk sac within the endometrial cavity.
Which one of the following conclusions about this pregnancy is consistent with the ultrasound evidence?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The first ultrasound evidence of pregnancy is a gestational sac. In a viable pregnancy, the gestational sac is always visible when the serum human chorionic gonadotropin level is 1500 to 2000 mIU/mL by transvaginal probe or about 3600 mIU/mL by transabdominal probe.

A normal early gestational sac is characterized by placement in the uterus that appears to be fundal, elliptical, eccentric to the endometrial stripe, and surrounded by a white fluffy, cloud-like ring (the decidual reaction). The gestational sac’s diameter is generally greater than 4 mm.

The yolk sac, the first confirmation of a true gestational sac, appears at approximately 5.5 weeks’ gestation. The appearance of the yolk sac helps to exclude a pseudosac. A pseudosac tends to be irregular, central, smaller, and without a decidual reaction.

At about 6 weeks, the embryo is first visible as a tiny speck in the gestational sac, usually close to the yolk sac and <5 mm long. When the pregnancy reaches 6.5 weeks after the last menstrual period, cardiac motion is usually readily apparent, and the embryo is 5 mm or longer.

Gestational age in days can be approximated by the following equation: embryonic pole length in millimeters + 42.

Key learning point: The gestational age that corresponds to ultrasound findings of an embryonic pole <5 mm long is 6 weeks.

B) INCORRECT:

An intrauterine pregnancy at 8 weeks’ gestation is usually characterized by a fetal pole filling most of the amniotic sac. Limb buds become apparent at approximately 9 weeks’ gestation.

C) INCORRECT:

An ectopic pregnancy can manifest with an intrauterine pseudosac. It is a small collection of fluid within the midline of the endometrial stripe but does not represent a true gestational sac.

D) INCORRECT:

An intrauterine pregnancy at 12 weeks is characterized by a mobile fetus with a moving body and limb buds. After 12 weeks, the biparietal diameter is a better measurement for dating.

E) INCORRECT:

An intrauterine pregnancy at 8 weeks’ gestation is usually characterized by a fetal pole filling most of the amniotic sac. Limb buds become apparent at approximately 9 weeks’ gestation.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old gravida 2, para 1 woman at 8 weeks' gestation who was recently seen for her first prenatal visit is found to have type A, Rh(D)-negative blood and presence of anti-I and anti-Lea antibodies. She can identify the man she thinks is most likely to be the father in the current pregnancy.
Her previous pregnancy was 3 years ago, with a different partner. During that pregnancy, she was Rh(D)-negative and antibody negative; she received Rh(D) immune globulin at 28 weeks' gestation and immediately after delivery. Her healthy singleton male infant was typed with AB-positive blood.
What is the most appropriate next step in this patient's care?

choices.text: Test the fetus's father for blood type and antibodies
Measure the titer of the anti-I and anti-Lea antibodies

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pregnancy termination would not be recommended because the fetus is not at risk for HDFN.

B) INCORRECT:

If the antibodies detected are known to be associated with HDFN (such as anti-D, anti-E, anti-K, and others) and paternity is assured, then the antigen status of the blood cells of the fetus's father should be assessed. Paternal Rh testing helps predict the fetal Rh type and can eliminate the need for unnecessary anti-D immunoglobulin (IgG) prophylaxis, should the father of the baby also be Rh-negative. If paternity is uncertain, then a maternal indirect Coombs test should be assessed to quantify the antibody titer. The critical titer is the level at which a particular antibody requires further evaluation (typically 1:16).

C) INCORRECT:

Measuring the titer of the anti-I and anti-Lea antibodies is not necessary because these antibodies are known to be unrelated to fetal hemolytic disease. Thus, a titer should not be quantified if anti-I or anti-Lea antibodies are detected on indirect Coombs test.

D) INCORRECT:

Administering Rh(D) immune globulin is not the most appropriate next step because the patient is at only 8 weeks' gestation without any potential bleeding concerns. Rh(D) immune globulin is traditionally administered between 28 and 34 weeks' gestation to most women with Rh(D)-negative blood; the dose may be omitted if paternity is certain or if the fetus is known to be Rh(D) negative (by cell-free DNA evaluation of maternal plasma or, in rare instances, by other methods). Rh(D) immune globulin is administered to the mother again after delivery if the fetal blood type is Rh(D) positive. Other indications where there is potential maternal and fetal blood mixture, and thus Rh(D) immune globulin should be administered, include threatened, spontaneous, or induced abortion; amniocentesis; chorionic villus sampling; ectopic pregnancy; bleeding associated with placenta previa or placenta abruption; abdominal trauma; and external cephalic version.

E) CORRECT:

Every woman should undergo blood typing (both ABO and Rh) and antibody screening (indirect Coombs test) at the first prenatal visit of each pregnancy. If she tests positive for non-Rh(D) antibodies, then the provider should determine whether the antibody has been associated with hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn (HDFN). Anti-I and anti-Lea antibodies have not been associated with HDFN, so no further evaluation is needed in this patient.

Key learning point: The most appropriate next step in care for a pregnant woman with Rh(D)-negative blood and positive anti-I and anti-Lea antibodies is no further evaluation.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old gravida 2, para 1 woman whose fetus has an estimated gestational age of 7 weeks and 2 days presents with her husband to ask about cell-free DNA testing to determine the sex of their fetus. The couple is hoping for a boy because their first child was a girl. Neither the patient nor the husband has a family history of genetic disorders.
In addition to facilitating further discussion and counseling, which one of the following statements is most appropriate to share with this couple regarding fetal sex testing in the United States?

choices.text: Fetal sex testing must be performed before 7 weeks’ gestation
Fetal sex testing is permissible with the consent of a local ethics committee
Fetal sex testing is permissible after 24 weeks’ gestation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fetal sex testing can be carried out reliably from 7 weeks’ gestation to identify the presence or absence of Y chromosome-specific sequences in the maternal plasma.

B) INCORRECT:

Fetal sex determination using cell-free DNA testing is permissible in the United States.

C) INCORRECT:

Fetal sex testing can be carried out reliably from 7 weeks’ gestation to identify the presence or absence of Y chromosome-specific sequences in the maternal plasma.

D) INCORRECT:

Fetal sex determination using cell-free DNA testing is permissible in the United States.

E) CORRECT:

Fetal sex determination using cell-free DNA testing is permissible in the United States. It is a well-established prenatal test that can be carried out reliably from 7 weeks’ gestation to identify the presence or absence of Y chromosome-specific sequences in the maternal plasma. When used for medical reasons, it reduces the need for invasive procedures.

The most common clinical indication for early fetal sex determination is in carriers of X-linked genetic disorders, such as Duchenne muscular dystrophy, for which male-bearing pregnancies are primarily at risk. For women who are carriers of X-linked conditions, early fetal sex determination using cell-free DNA testing can inform the choice of invasive testing. If a male fetus is identified, the woman can proceed to definitive diagnosis of the condition. If a female fetus is identified, an invasive test is not needed, and the associated miscarriage risk can be avoided.

Parents may choose to use cell-free DNA testing for nonmedical reasons, whether it be to balance the sex distribution of their children or for other nonmedical reasons. Although access to the test is permissible, the parents should be informed about ethical issues, including concerns for sexism and for reinforcement of gender inequality and preconceived gender roles.

The concern of using cell-free DNA testing for sex selection for nonmedical reasons is mainly a matter of sex-selective abortion. In the overwhelming majority of cases worldwide, female fetuses are aborted. Nonetheless, attempts to forbid the use of prenatal diagnosis and abortion for sex selection (other than for a medical reason) have had the adverse effect of making safe abortion less readily available for women who need such procedures for whatever reason. There is no specific ban on sex-selection abortions in the United States.

Key learning point: When parents request cell-free DNA fetal sex testing at 7 weeks’ gestation, the appropriate response is to inform them that this type of testing is permitted.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old gravida 2, para 1 woman at 35 weeks and 3 days' gestation reports an increase in clear vaginal fluid for the past 12 hours. She reports she has had no contractions, vaginal bleeding, fever, chills, abdominal pain, or dysuria. Fetal movements are regular.
The woman has received regular prenatal care, and her pregnancy has been uncomplicated. A screening test for group B streptococcus was to be performed at her next appointment. She has no relevant medical history and no known drug allergies. She takes prenatal vitamins and iron supplements.
Her current blood pressure is 118/68 mm Hg, her heart rate is 72 beats per minute, and her temperature is 36.9°C. Her abdomen is nontender. Her cervical examination shows fingertip dilation. There is pooling of clear fluid in the posterior vagina; a Nitrazine assay is positive for alkaline pH. Arborization (ferning) of dried vaginal fluid is seen on microscopy.
Electronic fetal monitoring shows a category I tracing, without contractions. The position of the vertex is confirmed by ultrasound.
Which one of the following management strategies is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Initiate treatment with magnesium sulfate and betamethasone, and plan for induction of labor
Initiate treatment with penicillin and terbutaline, and observe
Initiate treatment with penicillin and betamethasone, and plan for induction of labor
Initiate treatment with magnesium sulfate and terbutaline, and observe

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Magnesium sulfate for fetal neuroprotection is only recommended if the gestational age is less than 32 weeks.

B) INCORRECT:

If preterm prelabor rupture of membranes occurs between 34 and 37 weeks of gestation, it may be appropriate to provide expectant management. However, if the mother's group B streptococcal (GBS) colonization status is unknown, GBS prophylaxis should be administered regardless of whether expectant management or expedient delivery is performed.

C) INCORRECT:

The use of tocolytics (e.g., terbutaline) is not recommended for preterm prelabor rupture of membranes occurring between 34 and 37 weeks of gestation.

D) CORRECT:

Preterm prelabor rupture of membranes (PPROM) is defined as rupture of membranes before a fetal gestational age of 37 weeks and 0 days, in the absence of labor.

Expectant management vs. expedient delivery

Recommendations for management depend on the gestational age, reflecting a balance between the risks of preterm delivery and maternal hemorrhage (favoring expectant management) and the risks for possible intra-amniotic infection (favoring expedient delivery). The 2020 American College of Obstetrics and Gynecology (ACOG) guidelines recommend:

• Expedient delivery for prelabor rupture of membranes that occurs at or after 37 weeks of gestation.
• Expectant management for PPROM between 24 and 34 weeks of gestation
• Expectant management or expedient delivery for PPROM occurring between 34 and 37 weeks of gestation, and for PPROM before 24 weeks of gestation

Two well-designed, randomized controlled trials, comparing induced labor with expectant management among women with PPROM at 34 to 37 weeks of gestation, showed no significant differences in the rates of neonatal sepsis, respiratory distress syndrome, or cesarean delivery. However, combined data from the two studies did show a lower incidence of chorioamnionitis with induced labor (1.6% vs. 5.3%). Controversy persists regarding the timing of delivery, given the lack of relevant long-term follow-up data. When choosing expedient delivery, induction of labor is preferred unless contraindications are present (e.g., fetal distress, transverse lie), in which case a cesarean delivery is performed.

Group B streptococcus (GBS) prophylaxis and latency antibiotics

Patients presenting with PPROM and an unknown GBS colonization status should undergo a vagino-rectal swab for GBS culture and receive GBS prophylaxis empirically. Ampicillin and erythromycin are used in combination as latency antibiotics to prolong the time from the rupture of membranes to delivery. This combination decreases the risk of labor-inducing ascending infections (e.g., chorioamnionitis) and fetal infections after the rupture of membranes. Ampicillin also serves as GBS prophylaxis. Latency antibiotics are administered for PPROM occurring between 20 and 34 weeks of gestation. Between 34 and 37 weeks of gestation, latency antibiotics are administered if expectant management is chosen, and penicillin for GBS prophylaxis is administered if latency antibiotics are not initiated.

Tocolytics, antenatal corticosteroids, and fetal neuroprotection

Tocolysis is not recommended for PPROM occurring between 34 and 37 weeks of gestation and before 24 weeks of gestation. For PPROM occurring between 24 and 34 weeks of gestation, tocolysis may be considered to delay labor and allow for corticosteroids to be administered but their role in this setting is controversial. The use of antenatal glucocorticoids, such as betamethasone, after PPROM has been evaluated in several clinical trials and has been shown to reduce neonatal mortality, respiratory distress syndrome, intraventricular hemorrhage, and necrotizing enterocolitis. Current data suggest that antenatal glucocorticoids are not associated with an increased risk of maternal or neonatal infection, regardless of gestational age. A single course of glucocorticoids is recommended for pregnant women between 24 and 34 weeks of gestation who are at risk for preterm delivery. Between 34 and 37 weeks of gestation, a single dose of corticosteroids can be considered if the patient did not previously receive a dose of antenatal steroids, if there is no evidence of chorioamnionitis, and if delivery is anticipated to happen in 1–7 days. Magnesium sulfate for fetal neuroprotection is only recommended if the gestational age is less than 32 weeks.

Key learning point: For a pregnant woman with preterm prelabor rupture of membranes and a gestational age between 34 and 37 weeks, either expedient delivery or expectant management is acceptable but group B streptococcal prophylaxis should be administered and antenatal corticosteroid therapy should be considered.

E) INCORRECT:

Tocolytics (e.g., terbutaline, magnesium sulfate) are not recommended for PPROM occurring between 34 and 37 weeks of gestation. Magnesium sulfate for fetal neuroprotection is only recommended if the gestational age is less than 32 weeks.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old primigravida woman at 41 weeks and 5 days’ gestation by last menstrual period presents with painful contractions. Her membranes ruptured approximately 20 hours ago. The contractions have been occurring every 3 minutes for the past 5 hours.
The patient is healthy and has had an uncomplicated pregnancy; she declined induction of labor at 41 weeks’ gestation. A test for group B streptococcus performed at 36 weeks' gestation was negative.
The patient is 4 cm dilated. Electronic fetal monitoring reveals a category I tracing.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in this case?

choices.text: Treat the infant after delivery with ampicillin
Treat the mother if she develops fever or other features of infection
Treat the infant after delivery if he or she develops fever or other features of infection

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The results of a group B streptococcus (GBS) screening test are considered valid for only 5 weeks; after that, the negative predictive value of a negative test declines. Current recommendations are to test for GBS between 36 weeks, 0 days’ gestation and 37 weeks, 6 days’ gestation, which would ensure that the results are still valid during the period when most women go into labor. If the test was obtained early in this interval, and the patient goes into labor after 41 weeks’ gestation, then the results may become outdated. In this case, the patient's GBS screening test occurred more than 5 weeks before presentation, and it is possible that she has been colonized with GBS in the interim. Therefore, this patient should be managed as if her GBS status is unknown.

Indications for starting intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis in women with unknown GBS status include membrane rupture ≥18 hours before presentation, delivery at <37 weeks' gestation, maternal temperature ≥38.0°C, or a positive intrapartum GBS nucleic acid amplification test.

Key learning point: The maximum number of weeks before labor that a group B streptococcal screening test can be considered negative is 5.

B) INCORRECT:

Unlike the mother, the infant does not necessarily require treatment based on the duration of membrane rupture. If the infant develops fever or other features of infection, treatment would be warranted, but providing intrapartum prophylaxis to the mother is the most important next step in her care.

C) INCORRECT:

Given the duration of membrane rupture in this patient (≥18 hours), she should be started on immediate intrapartum prophylaxis. Waiting to treat her until she develops fever or other features of infection is not appropriate.

D) INCORRECT:

Given the duration of membrane rupture in this patient (≥18 hours), she should be started on immediate intrapartum prophylaxis. Unlike the mother, the infant does not necessarily require treatment based on the duration of membrane rupture. If the infant develops fever or other features of infection, treatment would be warranted.

E) INCORRECT:

The drug of choice for intrapartum prophylaxis is penicillin. Cefazolin is reserved for patients with penicillin allergy who have not experienced anaphylaxis, angioedema, respiratory distress, or urticaria after receiving penicillin or a cephalosporin.

questions.text:
A healthy 26-year-old gravida 2, para 1 woman at 36 weeks and 2 days’ gestation reports a reduction in fetal movements during the past 24 hours. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated. She denies any contractions or vaginal bleeding.
Her temperature is 37.4°C, her heart rate is 88 beats per minute, her respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute, and her oxygen saturation is 100% while she breathes ambient air. Her fundal height is 36 cm, and the rest of her examination is within normal limits.
The patient is placed on a monitor. The tocometer reveals three spontaneous contractions within the first 10 minutes, and the corresponding fetal heart tracing shows no evidence of fetal heart rate decelerations.
What is the most appropriate next step for this woman?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient’s CST was adequate (3 contractions within 10 minutes) and showed no variable decelerations, so she can be reassured that the incidence of stillbirth within one week is very low. Given these results, there is no indication for NST, BPP, admission to the hospital for observation, or induced delivery.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient’s CST was adequate (3 contractions within 10 minutes) and showed no variable decelerations, so she can be reassured that the incidence of stillbirth within one week is very low. Given these results, there is no indication for NST, BPP, admission to the hospital for observation, or induced delivery.

C) CORRECT:

A fetus exposed to hypoxia may show diminished movement, late decelerations, or oligohydramnios, because blood flow is preferentially directed to the brain and heart and away from the kidneys. Antenatal fetal assessments have been used since the 1970s to identify high-risk fetuses in order to prevent neurologic injury or death secondary to hypoxia, acidosis, or both.

Indications for intrauterine fetal assessment include any condition that may predispose the fetus to intrauterine demise or injury, including (but not limited to) gestational or pregestational diabetes mellitus, hypertension or preeclampsia, cardiac disease, renal disease, systemic lupus erythematosus, sickle cell disease, intrauterine growth restriction, oligohydramnios, isoimmunization, diminished fetal movement, and the mother’s experience of previous fetal demise. In general, these assessments should begin after 32 to 34 weeks’ gestation, unless otherwise indicated.

The most common fetal assessment techniques are the contraction stress test (CST), nonstress test (NST), biophysical profile (BPP), and modified biophysical profile. The negative predictive value is 99.8% for the NST and 99.9% for the CST, BPP, and modified BPP, as measured by the incidence of stillbirth within one week after a normal test.

A CST involves monitoring the fetal heart rate with uterine contractions, which can occur spontaneously or be induced by nipple stimulation or oxytocin administration. Oxygenation to the fetus worsens transiently with uterine contractions. In an already hypoxic fetus, the transient decrease in oxygenation leads to late decelerations. A CST is considered negative if there are at least three contractions present within 10 minutes and no late or significant variable decelerations.

This patient’s CST was adequate (3 contractions within 10 minutes) and showed no variable decelerations, so she can be reassured that the incidence of stillbirth within one week is very low. Given these results, there is no indication for NST, BPP, admission to the hospital for observation, or induced delivery.

An NST evaluates fetal heart rate reactivity or acceleration in response to fetal movement, which can be spontaneous or induced by vibroacoustic stimulation. A loss of reactivity raises suspicion for depressed neurologic function, which could be secondary to hypoxia or acidosis.

A BPP consists of an NST plus assessment of fetal breathing, fetal movement, fetal tone, and amniotic fluid volume. Each of these five categories is given a score of 0 if absent or 2 if present/reassuring. Obtained scores are added, with an overall score of 8 to 10 (normal), 6 (equivocal), and 4 or less (abnormal). A modified BPP consists of an NST plus assessment of amniotic fluid volume.

Key learning point: For a woman who reports a reduction in fetal movements at 36 weeks’ gestation and whose tocometer reveals at least three contractions within 10 minutes and no late decelerations, the risk for stillbirth within one week is very low.

D) INCORRECT:

Vibroacoustic stimulation has not been shown to have adequate utility for assessing fetal well-being.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient’s CST was adequate (3 contractions within 10 minutes) and showed no variable decelerations, so she can be reassured that the incidence of stillbirth within one week is very low. Given these results, there is no indication for NST, BPP, admission to the hospital for observation, or induced delivery.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old gravida 2, para 1 woman at 11 weeks’ gestation presents for follow-up after a recent first-trimester combined screen showed a low level of pregnancy-associated plasma protein A, an elevated level of beta human chorionic gonadotropin, and ultrasound evidence of increased nuchal translucency thickness. She is considering terminating the pregnancy.
What additional testing, if any, is indicated for this patient?

choices.text: Deferral of further testing until 20 weeks’ gestation
Repeat measurement of pregnancy-associated plasma protein A and beta human chorionic gonadotropin now

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient is considering possible pregnancy termination, so it is necessary to confirm the suspected diagnosis of trisomy 21 as soon as possible.

B) CORRECT:

A first-trimester combined screen for trisomy 21 consists of the following three components in addition to maternal age:

• Ultrasound measurement of fetal nuchal translucency
• Measurement of serum beta human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)
• Measurement of pregnancy-associated plasma protein A (PAPP-A)

This screening, typically conducted at 9 to 13 weeks’ gestation, has a detection rate of 80% to 90% for trisomy 21; the false-positive rate is 5%. The typical pattern associated with trisomy 21 is a low PAPP-A level, an elevated beta hCG level, and increased nuchal translucency thickness on ultrasound.

If all three tests on this combined screen are positive, the diagnosis of trisomy 21 can be confirmed by cytogenetic analysis of fetal cells obtained by chorionic villus sampling (CVS) or amniocentesis. CVS is generally conducted at 9 to 14 weeks’ gestation, and amniocentesis is generally offered at 15 to 20 weeks’ gestation.

The fetal cells collected during CVS or amniocentesis can be analyzed using any of the following:

• Traditional karyotype testing to detect changes in chromosome number (aneuploidy) or structure
• Fluorescence in situ hybridization to identify the presence, absence, or rearrangement of specific DNA segments
• Chromosome microarray, which can identify submicroscopic duplications, deletions, and rearrangements

This patient is considering possible pregnancy termination, so it is necessary to confirm the suspected diagnosis of trisomy 21 as soon as possible. Given that the patient is at 11 weeks' gestation, CVS is the most appropriate test.

Cell-free DNA testing is another option to screen for certain chromosomal abnormalities in a fetus. It involves examining a maternal blood sample for abnormal amounts of pregnancy DNA from chromosomes 21, 18, and 13. This test has a 99% negative predictive value and, in high-risk populations, an 83% positive predictive value for trisomy 21. If a positive result is obtained, diagnostic testing, such as CVS or amniocentesis, is warranted.

Key learning point: The confirmatory test for a woman who has serologic and ultrasound evidence of possible trisomy 21 at 9 to 14 weeks’ gestation is chorionic villus sampling.

C) INCORRECT:

There is no need to wait until 20 weeks’ gestation, as CVS and amniocentesis can both be performed before then.

D) INCORRECT:

Amniocentesis is not typically performed until at least 15 weeks’ gestation.

E) INCORRECT:

Repeat laboratory screening tests, such as PAPP-A and beta hCG, would not be confirmatory and, therefore, are not indicated.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old woman who is pregnant in her second trimester asks about genetic screening for diseases that are prevalent in her family. She has a personal history of alcohol use disorder and intellectual disability. She is currently sober but used alcohol in the first trimester. She was on lithium for the treatment of bipolar disorder at the time she became pregnant. Her 18-month-old son has been diagnosed with fetal alcohol syndrome.
Her family history is notable for spina bifida in an aunt, fragile X syndrome in a first cousin, and fetal alcohol syndrome and intellectual disability in several other cousins. Her sister, who is also pregnant, recently underwent prenatal genetic testing and had normal results.
For which one of the following issues would it be appropriate to offer prenatal genetic testing to this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neural tube defects, such as spina bifida and anencephaly, can be detected antenatally by ultrasound and do not require prenatal genetic testing.

B) INCORRECT:

Neural tube defects, such as spina bifida and anencephaly, can be detected antenatally by ultrasound and do not require prenatal genetic testing.

C) CORRECT:

Prenatal genetic testing may be offered to mothers who are at risk of carrying a fetus with a genetic disorder or who have a positive prenatal screening test. The genetic testing is performed on fetal tissue obtained from either amniocentesis or chorionic villus sampling. The fetal DNA is examined for specific inherited genetic diseases, or exome or genome sequencing may be performed.

Fragile X syndrome is an inherited form of intellectual disability that is more common in boys than girls. It occurs when a DNA segment known as the CGG triplet repeat is expanded on the FMR1 gene.

Key learning point: A pregnant woman with a personal and family history of intellectual disability should undergo genetic testing for fragile X syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Fetal alcohol syndrome is caused by excessive maternal ethanol ingestion during pregnancy and is not a genetically transmitted problem.

E) INCORRECT:

Exposure to lithium is associated with cardiac abnormalities and warrants counseling, but genetic testing would not be helpful to evaluate this issue.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 37 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labor. She has received routine prenatal care, but she has not been tested for group B streptococcal (GBS) colonization. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child were complicated by an infection with GBS that resulted in sepsis in the newborn. Current medications include folic acid and a multivitamin. Vital signs are within normal limits. The abdomen is nontender and contractions are felt every 4 minutes. There is clear amniotic fluid pooling in the vagina. The fetus is in a cephalic presentation. The fetal heart rate is 140/min. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain vaginal-rectal swab for GBS culture
Obtain vaginal-rectal swab for nucleic acid amplification testing and intravenous penicillin administration

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient is most likely colonized by GBS and should receive a different intervention to avoid intrapartum transmission and a subsequent negative outcome in her unborn child.

B) INCORRECT:

Culture of GBS is indicated at 36 0/7–37 6/7 weeks' gestation for diagnosis of maternal GBS colonization. However, patients with GBS bacteriuria during pregnancy or a history of a previous newborn with GBS infection (as in this patient) require prophylaxis. Therefore, she does not require further testing, as it would not influence the treatment.

C) CORRECT:

Intrapartum administration of intravenous penicillin G is used for the prophylaxis of neonatal GBS infection. Maternal GBS colonization is a major risk factor for early-onset neonatal infection and sepsis. Routine screening for GBS colonization of all pregnant women via culture of vaginal and rectal swabs is indicated between 36 0/7–37 6/7 weeks' gestation. Women with GBS bacteriuria occurring anytime during pregnancy or history of a previous newborn with GBS infection, as in this patient, should receive routine prophylactic antibiotics and do not have to undergo prior screening for GBS colonization.

Other maternal risk factors for GBS infection that serve as indications for antibiotic prophylaxis in patients with unknown antepartum culture status include fever, preterm labor, premature rupture of membranes, or positive intrapartum nucleic acid amplification testing for GBS.

D) INCORRECT:

Nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) can be used for rapid intrapartum diagnosis of maternal GBS colonization in women with an unknown culture status. However, NAAT is not routinely used because of its low sensitivity compared to standard GBS culture. Moreover, the management of cases with a possible maternal GBS colonization and an unknown antepartum culture status should be based on maternal risk factors rather than NAAT results. Intrapartum administration of intravenous penicillin G is used for the prophylaxis of neonatal GBS infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Colonization or active infections (e.g., chorioamnionitis) do not routinely justify a cesarean delivery. However, if an infection presents along with fetal distress or there is any other standard obstetric indication (e.g., insufficient maternal contractions), the patient would require a cesarean delivery.
questions.hint: This patient's first child had sepsis due to a GBS infection. It is essential to prevent the infection from recurring in her second child.

questions.text: Two days after delivery, a newborn is brought to the clinic because of a red, irritated eye with yellow discharge. The mother had an unmedicated vaginal delivery at home; the patient did not receive any routine postpartum medications. Ophthalmic examination shows eyelid edema, conjunctival injection, and copious yellow mucopurulent discharge from the right eye. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?

choices.text: Oral erythromycin administered to the infant
IV ceftriaxone administered to the infant
Topical erythromycin administered to the infant
Oral doxycycline administered to the mother
Oral amoxicillin administered to the mother

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral erythromycin is the first-line treatment for chlamydial neonatal conjunctivitis, which typically occurs 5–14 days after delivery and manifests with mild eyelid swelling and watery or mucopurulent ocular discharge. This patient's presentation is consistent with NGC, for which oral erythromycin is not indicated as either prophylaxis or treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous or intramuscular ceftriaxone is the treatment of choice in infants with NGC. However, ceftriaxone is not used for NGC prophylaxis.

C) CORRECT:

Topical erythromycin ointment should be applied within 1 hour of birth to prevent NGC. In most states in the US, prophylaxis against NGC is required by law. If left untreated, NGC may result in corneal scarring and blindness. After confirming NGC (using culture and Gram stain or PCR), systemic treatment with either an IV or IM third-generation cephalosporin (e.g., ceftriaxone) is indicated. In addition, the eyes should be flushed with saline until the discharge clears.
Image Description:

The eyelids are swollen, with purulent exudate forming crusts around them. Below the crusts there may be a large reservoir of pus. Special care should be taken and safety goggles should be worn when examining the eyes.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral doxycycline may be administered to treat mothers of newborns who have newborn conjunctivitis due to an infection with Chlamydia trachomatis. However, administration of oral doxycycline (as a prophylactic measure) in pregnant women is contraindicated because it may lead to bone damage and deposits in teeth (yellowing of the primary teeth) in the offspring.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral amoxicillin can be used to treat infection with Chlamydia trachomatis in pregnant women and, therefore, help prevent chlamydial neonatal conjunctivitis (CNC). However, CNC typically occurs 5–14 days after delivery and manifests with mild eyelid swelling and watery or mucopurulent ocular discharge. This patient's presentation is more consistent with NGC. Amoxicillin is not the first-line treatment for infection with Neisseria gonorrhea and, therefore, would have not prevented this newborn's NGC.
questions.hint: This patient presents with conjunctival injection and copious yellow mucopurulent discharge 2 days after birth, all of which are consistent with neonatal gonococcal conjunctivitis (NGC). NGC is typically caused by ophthalmic colonization of the newborn's conjunctiva during delivery from mothers with Neisseria gonorrhea infection.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 24 weeks' gestation comes to the office for a prenatal visit. She feels well. Her earlier pregnancy was uncomplicated. This is her 4th prenatal visit. She had an ultrasound scan 2 weeks ago that showed a live intrauterine pregnancy consistent with a 22-week gestation with no anomalies. She had a normal Pap smear 2 years ago. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 24-week gestation. Her blood group and type is B positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Swab for Group B streptococcus culture

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Screening for gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) with an oral glucose challenge test is recommended for every pregnant patient at 24–28 weeks' gestation, or earlier in patients with increased risk of undiagnosed type 2 diabetes (e.g., due to obesity and GDM in a previous pregnancy). Early diagnosis and treatment of gestational diabetes mellitus are important to prevent complications of this condition, including gestational hypertension, preeclampsia, and shoulder dystocia due to fetal macrosomia.

Key learning point: All pregnant women should be screened for gestational diabetes with an oral glucose challenge test between 24 and 28 weeks’ gestation.

B) INCORRECT:

Rh antibody testing should be performed in all Rh-negative pregnant women between 28–29 weeks' gestation to screen for circulating Rh antibodies. Although screening can be performed earlier, Rh antibody testing is not necessary for this Rh-positive patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Screening for Group B streptococcus (GBS) by vaginal and rectal swab is performed from 36+0 to 37+6 weeks' gestation to evaluate for colonization that could potentially lead to neonatal infection or chorioamnionitis. Women who are positive for GBS should be treated with intrapartum penicillin G, or clindamycin or erythromycin in patients allergic to penicillin.

D) INCORRECT:

Biophysical profile is used to screen for pregnancies where there is an increased risk of antenatal fetal death. It is generally performed after 32 weeks' gestation.

E) INCORRECT:

Tdap vaccination is usually performed between 27–36 weeks' gestation, to booster maternal immunity to pertussis and to maximize the passive transfer of protective antibodies to the neonate.
questions.hint: At 24–28 weeks' gestation, screening for a condition associated with fetal macrosomia is recommended.

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravid woman at 16 weeks' gestation comes to the office for a routine prenatal visit. She is asymptomatic and has no history of serious illness. Her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F) and blood pressure is 108/60 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 16-week gestation. A quadruple screening test shows maternal serum α-fetoprotein level of 3 times the median and normal levels of serum β-human chorionic gonadotropin, estriol, and inhibin A. Which of the following is most likely to account for these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

MSAFP levels are not typically increased in cases of isolated fetal hydrocephalus.

B) INCORRECT:

A molar pregnancy typically results in low levels of MSAFP, low levels of unconjugated estriol, increased levels of inhibin A, and extremely high levels of β-hCG.

C) CORRECT:

Increased levels of MSAFP with normal levels of β-hCG, inhibin A, and unconjugated estriol are characteristic of open neural tube defects (e.g., myelomeningocele, anencephaly) and abdominal wall defects (gastroschisis, omphalocele). The diagnosis can be confirmed prenatally in most cases via ultrasound.

Other possible causes of elevated MSAFP include miscalculated gestational age, multiple gestations, fetal death, and placental abnormalities.

D) INCORRECT:

Fetal trisomy 18 would typically result in decreased levels of MSAFP, unconjugated estriol, and β-hCG.

E) INCORRECT:

Fetal trisomy 21 would typically result in decreased levels of MSAFP and unconjugated estriol as well as increased levels of inhibin A and β-hCG.
questions.hint: Isolated elevation of maternal serum α-fetoprotein (MSAFP) levels can be seen in a certain developmental defect associated with folate deficiency.

questions.text:
