A 33-year-old primigravid woman comes for a follow-up prenatal visit at 18 weeks' gestation. Ultrasonography at 12 weeks' gestation showed a nuchal translucency above the 99th percentile. At that visit, pregnancy-associated plasma protein A was decreased to 2 standard deviations below the mean. A chorionic villus sampling was performed, which showed a 47, XX karyotype. At today's visit, vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with an 18-week gestation. Ultrasonography shows shortened femur length, shortened middle phalanges of the fifth digits with clinodactyly, and a hypoplastic nasal bone. A quad screening test would most likely show which of the following sets of findings?



α-Fetoprotein
Estriol
β-hCG
Inhibin A



A
Decreased
decreased
increased
increased


B
Normal
normal
normal
normal


C
Decreased
decreased
decreased
decreased


D
Decreased
decreased
decreased
normal


E
Increased
normal
normal
normal
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The quad screen test should be performed at 15–22 weeks' gestation and can help to diagnose Down syndrome and other fetal aneuploidies (e.g., trisomy 18), as well as open neural tube and abdominal wall defects. Down syndrome pregnancies are associated with significantly decreased α-fetoprotein and free estriol levels and a marked increase in β-hCG and inhibin A levels in the maternal serum (see “Overview of quad and triple screening tests” table).

In addition to increased nuchal translucency and decreased PAPP-A levels, first trimester screening in a Down syndrome pregnancy would show increased β-hCG levels.

B) INCORRECT:

Normal findings in all quad screen markers are consistent with a normal fetus but are concerning for trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome) in a fetus with a suspected aneuploidy (based on the 47, XX karyotype). While Patau syndrome can also manifest with increased nuchal translucency and decreased PAPP-A during first-trimester screening, as well as a 47, XX karyotype, this patient's shortened femur length, shortened fifth digits with clinodactyly, and hypoplastic nasal bone are indicative of Down syndrome. Ultrasound findings suggestive of Patau syndrome include rocker-bottom feet, microcephaly or holoprosencephaly, and polydactyly (rather than clinodactyly).

C) INCORRECT:

A mild decrease in all quad screen markers is consistent with Turner syndrome. Though Turner syndrome can also manifest with increased nuchal translucency (due to lymphatic dysplasia), shortened femur length, and decreased PAPP-A levels, this patient's chorionic villus sampling showed a 47, XX karyotype, which is not consistent with the 45, XO karyotype that is characteristic of Turner syndrome.

A decrease in all quad screen markers is also consistent with trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome), though inhibin A can also be normal in this condition. While Edwards syndrome can also manifest with increased nuchal translucency and decreased PAPP-A during first-trimester screening, as well as a 47, XX karyotype, this patient's shortened femur length, shortened fifth digits with clinodactyly, and hypoplastic nasal bone are indicative of Down syndrome. Ultrasound findings typical of Edwards syndrome include rocker-bottom feet and clenched fists with overlapping of the third and fourth digits by the second and fifth digits, respectively (rather than clinodactyly).

D) INCORRECT:

A decrease in α-fetoprotein, free estriol, and β-hCG with normal or decreased inhibin A is consistent with trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome). While Edwards syndrome can also manifest with increased nuchal translucency and decreased PAPP-A during first-trimester screening, as well as a 47, XX karyotype, this patient's shortened femur length, shortened fifth digits with clinodactyly, and hypoplastic nasal bone are indicative of Down syndrome. Ultrasound findings typical of Edwards syndrome include rocker-bottom feet and clenched fists with overlapping of the third and fourth digits by the second and fifth digits, respectively (rather than clinodactyly).

E) INCORRECT:

An isolated increase in α-fetoprotein during pregnancy is characteristic of fetal neural tube defects or open abdominal wall defects such as gastroschisis or omphalocele. While some of these defects (such as omphalocele) may be associated with an increase in nuchal translucency, first-trimester fetal screening would show normal PAPP-A levels and a 46, XX karyotype. Furthermore, none of these conditions would involve shortened femur length, shortened fifth digits with clinodactyly, or a hypoplastic nasal bone.
questions.hint: Increased nuchal translucency, decreased pregnancy-associated plasma protein A (PAPP-A) levels, shortened femur length, shortened fifth digits with clinodactyly, and a hypoplastic nasal bone in a fetus with a 47, XX karyotype are features highly suggestive of trisomy 21 (Down syndrome).

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the office for preconceptional advice. She has been married for 2 years and would like to conceive within the next year. Menses occur at regular 30-day intervals and last 4 days with normal flow. She does not smoke or drink alcohol and follows a balanced diet. She takes no medications. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 55 kg (121 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Physical examination, including pelvic examination, shows no abnormalities. She has adequate knowledge of the fertile days of her menstrual cycle. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient at this time?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Supplementation of folic acid (0.4–0.8 mg/day) is recommended in all patients trying to conceive. Ideally, women should begin taking a supplement ≥ 4 weeks before trying to conceive and continue with this dose until 12 weeks of gestational age to meet the increased demand of folate due to fetal neural tube development and maternal and fetal erythropoiesis. If there is a folate deficiency, neural tube defects (e.g., anencephaly, meningomyelocele) and megaloblastic anemia may occur.

B) INCORRECT:

In the absence of severe deficiency, excessive intake of vitamin A is contraindicated in pregnant women and women who may become pregnant within the next 60 days. Vitamin A doses greater than the recommended dietary allowance in pregnancy (> 770 mcg/day or > 2560 units/day) may cause craniofacial malformations or central nervous system, heart, or thymus abnormalities in the fetus.

C) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 supplementation is recommended for pregnant women who adhere to a vegan diet since vitamin B12 is mainly found in red meat, fish, and dairy products. Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to maternal and fetal megaloblastic anemia. This patient does not follow a vegan diet and is not yet pregnant, making vitamin B12 supplementation unnecessary.

D) INCORRECT:

Iron supplementation of 30–60 mg/d is recommended during pregnancy to meet the increased iron demand due to maternal and fetal erythropoiesis. Iron deficiency in pregnancy may cause maternal and fetal anemia and increases the risk of placental insufficiency. Since this patient shows no symptoms of iron deficiency anemia, such as fatigue or pallor, iron supplementation is not necessary prior to conception.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients who are underweight can experience difficulty conceiving. If the patient were underweight and having problems becoming pregnant, gaining weight might be advised. Gaining extra weight prior to conception is not necessary in this case, as the woman has a normal BMI. Over the course of pregnancy, she should gain 25–35 lbs (about 11–16 kg).
questions.hint: Which of the following is most likely to decrease the risk of neural tube defects such as spina bifida and anencephaly in the fetus?

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 12 weeks' gestation comes to the office for her initial prenatal visit. She feels well. She was treated for genital herpes one year ago and gonorrhea 3 months ago. Medications include folic acid and a multivitamin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 12-week gestation. Urine dipstick is positive for leukocyte esterase and nitrite. Urine culture shows Escherichia coli (> 100,000 colony forming units/mL). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gentamicin should be avoided in this patient because aminoglycosides are teratogenic and can cause irreversible bilateral deafness in the fetus. While aminoglycosides may be administered in nonpregnant patients as a component of second-line treatment for pyelonephritis with either aminopenicillins and beta-lactamase inhibitors or cephalosporins, they are not generally used in the treatment of cystitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole is the first-line drug for uncomplicated cystitis in nonpregnant women and a second-line antibiotic for the treatment of urinary tract infections in pregnant women in the 2nd and 3rd trimesters (except in the last month of pregnancy). However, the drug should be avoided in this patient because trimethoprim is a folate antagonist, which may cause fetal neural tube defects in the first trimester of pregnancy.

C) INCORRECT:

Asymptomatic bacteriuria should always be treated promptly during pregnancy. This patient is at a higher risk of developing pyelonephritis from asymptomatic bacteriuria than a nonpregnant woman because, during pregnancy, the widened ureters and increased glucose levels in the urine facilitate the ascension of organisms to the kidney. Furthermore, if left untreated, there is also an increased risk of prematurity and low birth weight. In nonpregnant patients, asymptomatic bacteriuria does not require treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Ciprofloxacin is frequently used to treat complicated urinary tract infections in nonpregnant patients. However, fluoroquinolones are contraindicated during pregnancy. As there are other approved antibiotic agents, ciprofloxacin should be avoided in this pregnant patient.

E) CORRECT:

Amoxicillin/clavulanate is a first-line antibiotic agent for asymptomatic bacteriuria during pregnancy. Pregnancy increases the risk of bacteriuria and recurrent urinary tract infections because of increased pressure on the bladder from the growing uterus, urinary stasis, and immunosuppression. Screening for asymptomatic bacteriuria is recommended for all pregnant women in the first trimester. Asymptomatic bacteriuria during pregnancy should always be treated since it increases the risk of pyelonephritis in the mother, as well as preterm delivery and low birth weight.

Other antibiotic agents used to treat cystitis that are safe during pregnancy include oral cephalosporins (e.g., cefpodoxime, cephalexin), fosfomycin, and nitrofurantoin (during the 2nd and 3rd trimesters). Follow-up urine culture is recommended 1–2 weeks after completion of treatment to ensure eradication of bacteriuria.
questions.hint: This patient has no urinary frequency or dysuria, but her urinalysis is positive for leukocyte esterase and nitrite, and her urine culture grows E. coli, all of which indicates asymptomatic bacteriuria.

questions.text: A 17-year-old primigravid girl at 30 weeks' gestation presents for a routine prenatal visit. She has attended all of her prenatal screening appointments so far, which showed no abnormalities. Immunizations are up-to-date. She takes prenatal supplements. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a fundal height consistent with a 30-week gestation. Just before leaving the consulting room, she mentions that she does not intend to come for any more prenatal appointments because she lives too far away. The patient should be counseled that refusing further prenatal screening increases the risk of which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Myelomeningocele is a type of neural tube defect (NTD), which is the most common congenital malformation of the central nervous system. Prenatal screening for NTDs includes measurement of maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein at 16–18 weeks' gestation or ultrasound examination between 18–20 weeks' gestation. Since this patient is at 30 weeks of gestation and all of her previous prenatal visits were normal, discontinuing prenatal checkups now will not increase the risk of myelomeningocele.

B) INCORRECT:

Fetal macrosomia can result from maternal gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM). All pregnant women are initially screened for GDM with an oral glucose challenge test between 24–28 weeks of gestation. Since this patient is currently at 30 weeks' gestation and all of her previous prenatal visits were normal, the likelihood of her having GDM is very low. Therefore, discontinuing further prenatal care is unlikely to increase the risk of macrosomia in this fetus.

C) INCORRECT:

Congenital rubella syndrome is caused by the transplacental transfer of the rubella virus from an infected mother to her fetus. All pregnant women (unless there is evidence of immunity) are screened for rubella antibodies at the initial prenatal visit. Since this patient's immunizations are up to date and all of her previous prenatal visits showed no abnormalities, discontinuing further prenatal visits after 30 weeks of gestation is unlikely to increase the risk of congenital rubella infection.

D) CORRECT:

Neonatal sepsis can result from infection with Group B streptococcus (GBS), which colonizes the maternal genital tract in 15–40% of pregnant women. Transmission to the fetus can occur after the rupture of membranes or during labor (i.e., passage through the birth canal). Therefore, prenatal screening for GBS is performed in all pregnant women between 36 0/7 and 37 6/7 weeks of gestation via culture and gram staining of vaginal and rectal swabs. If this patient refuses further prenatal screening after 30 weeks' gestation, she will not be screened for GBS, thus increasing her child's risk of neonatal sepsis. Moreover, GBS can lead to urinary tract infections, cystitis, pyelonephritis, and chorioamnionitis during pregnancy, all of which can be avoided by screening and treatment. Patients with a positive screening test for GBS should receive intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis with IV penicillin G or ampicillin.

E) INCORRECT:

Hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn (HDFN) most commonly results from a Rhesus (Rh) or ABO incompatibility between the mother and fetus. Rh incompatibility is more likely to cause severe symptoms in the newborn. Therefore, screening Rh-negative mothers for anti-D antibodies takes place at the initial prenatal visit with further anti-D antibody testing at 28 weeks' gestation. Since this patient is already at 30 weeks of gestation and all of her previous prenatal visits showed no abnormalities, discontinuing prenatal visits at this point would not increase the risk of HDFN.
questions.hint: Think about the prenatal screening tests that women usually undergo after 30 weeks' gestation.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 36 weeks' gestation comes to the office for a prenatal visit. She feels well. Fetal movements are adequate. This is her seventh prenatal visit. She had ultrasonography performed 1 month ago that showed a live intrauterine pregnancy consistent with a 32-week gestation with no anomalies. Her most recent Pap smear was 1 year ago and showed no abnormalities. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 36-week gestation. Her blood group is A, Rh-negative. Which of the following health maintenance recommendations is most appropriate at this time?

choices.text: Swab for group B Streptococcus culture

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A complete blood count (CBC) should be performed in all pregnant women in the first trimester and again between 24 weeks' and 28 weeks' gestation to identify potential anemia, clotting disorders, infection, and/or immunodeficiency. This patient most likely had a CBC at a previous visit.

B) INCORRECT:

Transabdominal Doppler ultrasonography is used to assess fetal hemodynamics (e.g., umbilical blood flow, fetal heart rate, fetoplacental circulation). It is a primary surveillance tool in high-risk (e.g., intrauterine growth restriction, maternal hypertension) and/or twin pregnancies and can also be used to identify the presence of fetal anemia and cardiac abnormalities. This patient does not have a high-risk or twin pregnancy.

C) INCORRECT:

An oral glucose tolerance test should be performed in all pregnant women, ideally between 24 weeks' and 28 weeks' gestation. An oral glucose tolerance test should be performed earlier if the patient is obese and/or has personal or family history of diabetes. High glucose levels may indicate gestational diabetes, which requires further management, as it is associated with an increased risk of morbidity (e.g., maternal preeclampsia, fetal macrosomia). This patient most likely had this test at a previous visit.

D) CORRECT:

A screening test for group B Streptococcus (GBS) should be performed in all pregnant women between 36 0/7 and 37 6/7 weeks of gestation since ∼ 25% of women are asymptomatic carriers of GBS. For the test, a sterile swab is used to take samples from the vagina and rectum for culture. If the results are positive, antibiotic prophylaxis for neonatal GBS infection (e.g., IV penicillin) should be given to the mother during labor to prevent infection of the newborn, which can result in pneumonia, meningitis, and/or sepsis in the newborn. GBS prophylaxis is also indicated for preterm labor (< 37 weeks), prolonged membrane rupture, fever during labor, if a previous child had a neonatal GBS infection, or if a GBS swab was positive at any time during pregnancy.

E) INCORRECT:

Rh antibody testing should be performed in all Rh-negative pregnant women between 28 weeks' and 29 weeks' gestation to screen for circulating Rh antibodies (Ab). Rh-negative patients who are not yet Rh-sensitized (no circulating Ab) should receive a dose of Rh immunoglobulin (RhIG) to prevent the production of Rh antibodies during the rest of their pregnancy and thereby prevent fetal hemolytic anemia in a later pregnancy with an Rh-positive baby. This patient, who is at 36 weeks' gestation, most likely had Rh antibody testing at a previous visit.
questions.hint: The most appropriate health maintenance recommendations at this time are aimed at reducing the risk of neonatal sepsis.

questions.text: A previously healthy 29-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 35 weeks' gestation comes to the office for a routine prenatal visit. Current medications include folic acid and a multivitamin. A rectovaginal swab culture grows Streptococcus agalactiae. Which of the following is the most appropriate intervention to decrease vertical transmission of this organism?

choices.text: Schedule delivery of the fetus via C-section

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Scheduling delivery of the fetus via C-section would not be appropriate for this patient. Colonization with GBS or active infection (e.g., chorioamnionitis) is not a routine indication for C-section. Cesarean deliveries are reserved for patients with standard obstetric indications (e.g., insufficient maternal contractions, fetal malposition, cephalopelvic disproportion) or severe infections that present along with fetal distress.

B) INCORRECT:

Benzathine penicillin G is used in the treatment of syphilis and infection with Streptococcus pyogenes (which is sensitive to bacitracin, unlike the organism cultured in this patient). While GBS infection can also be treated with penicillin G, administration of the antibiotic at this time would not be appropriate because it does not eliminate the risk of recolonization at the time of delivery.

C) INCORRECT:

Abstaining from breastfeeding due to a group B streptococcal (GBS) infection would not be appropriate in this patient. GBS can be passed to the neonate during delivery but not through breast milk. Reasons to permanently abstain from breastfeeding include maternal infections with retroviruses (e.g., HIV and human T-cell lymphotropic virus) or ebola virus, or classic galactosemia in the infant. Indications for temporarily abstaining include active herpes infection and concomitant use of toxic medications (e.g., tetracyclines).

D) CORRECT:

Ampicillin (or penicillin G) is administered in the intrapartum period as prophylaxis for neonatal GBS disease. Maternal GBS colonization is a major risk factor for early-onset neonatal infection and sepsis. Prenatal screening for GBS colonization (culture of vaginal and rectal swabs) is indicated in all pregnant women from 36+0 to 37+6 weeks' gestation and intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis is indicated in all women with a positive screening. It is also indicated in women with GBS bacteriuria occurring any time during pregnancy and in those who have previously given birth to a newborn with GBS infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Intravenous immune globulin (IVIG) is administered postpartum as prophylaxis in several scenarios, e.g., in neonates exposed to measles or in the case of Rh incompatibility. IVIG is not indicated in patients with a swab that is positive for group B streptococcus (GBS).
questions.hint: Group B Streptococcus (GBS) is a bacitracin-resistant, β-hemolytic, gram-positive coccus.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman reports that she had a positive home pregnancy test. Her last menstrual period was 7 weeks ago. She describes having morning sickness, with nausea and vomiting, and is taking herbal remedies that have not helped. She has had a 3-kg (6.6-lb) weight loss during this time. She weighs 110 kg (242 lb). Her serum electrolytes, amylase levels, thyroid-stimulating hormone levels, liver-function studies, and urinalysis are within normal limits. Which of the following management recommendations is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Admit her to the hospital for intravenous hydration
Initiate treatment with a histamine-2-receptor antagonist
Recommend that she include some fat content with each meal
Recommend that she eat frequent, small, bland meals

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous hydration with multivitamins (including thiamine) and antiemetic agents is indicated as first-line treatment for women with hyperemesis gravidarum, which is characterized by persistent nausea and vomiting associated with ketosis and weight loss (>5% of prepregnancy weight).

B) INCORRECT:

Pharmacologic options for treating hyperemesis gravidarum include vitamin B6, doxylamine (an antihistamine), and metoclopramide. A histamine-2-receptor antagonist would not be effective.

C) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoid therapy is reserved for the most refractory cases of hyperemesis gravidarum, which is characterized by persistent nausea and vomiting associated with ketosis and weight loss (>5% of prepregnancy weight).

D) INCORRECT:

Behavioral and dietary modifications are the first-line therapy for nausea and vomiting in early pregnancy. High-fat meals are not known to be effective for nausea and vomiting in early pregnancy.

E) CORRECT:

Behavioral and dietary modifications are the first-line therapy for nausea and vomiting in early pregnancy. Recommendations include avoiding exposure to triggers for nausea (common ones include fatty or spicy foods and iron tablets), eating small amounts of food several times a day, drinking fluids between meals, and consuming foods that are bland, dry, and high in protein.

Nausea and vomiting that persist despite these behavioral and dietary modifications and that are associated with ketosis and weight loss (>5% of prepregnancy weight) are considered hyperemesis gravidarum. This condition can cause volume depletion, nutritional deficiencies, liver-function abnormalities, electrolyte and acid-base disturbances, and even death. The reported incidence is 0.3% to 1.0%.

Key learning point: Nausea and vomiting in early pregnancy with weight loss of less than 5% and no abnormal laboratory findings is most likely to be attributable to morning sickness.
questions.hint: Nausea and vomiting are common conditions of pregnancy that occur in up to 90% of pregnancies.

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravid woman comes to the office for a prenatal visit at 36 weeks' gestation because of sharp lower back pain for 2 weeks. The pain is worse when she carries groceries and radiates to her posterior thighs. Two days ago, she had an episode of intense suprapubic pain while walking up the stairs to her apartment. She has not had any changes in bowel movements or urination. Examination of the back shows bilateral pain along the sacroiliac joint area when her legs are flexed, abducted, and externally rotated with the heel placed on the contralateral knee. She has difficulty actively raising either leg while the knee is extended. Hip flexor strength is limited by pain. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Bed rest and fetal heart rate monitoring

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The pelvic girdle relaxes during pregnancy to facilitate passage of the fetus through the birth canal. This relaxation can result in pelvic pain that is mistaken for lower back pain. Heat application and physical therapy are the main treatment modalities for pelvic girdle pain in pregnancy. Physical therapy can assist in strengthening the muscles that support the pelvic girdle, thereby stabilizing joints and decreasing pain. Additional nonpharmacological treatment options include cold therapy and manual therapy (e.g., massage, spinal manipulation) as well as pelvic support belts. If pharmacological treatment is required, acetaminophen is preferred. For patients who do not respond to other forms of treatment, local slow-release corticosteroid injections may also be considered.

B) INCORRECT:

Intraarticular corticosteroid (e.g., triamcinolone) injections are commonly used in the treatment of osteoarthritis, inflammatory or autoimmune arthritides (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, juvenile idiopathic arthritis), and greater trochanteric pain syndrome. However, the location (isolated lower back and pelvic girdle pain) and onset (new-onset in advanced pregnancy) of this patient's pain in the absence of other symptoms (e.g., morning stiffness, joint swelling) make these conditions unlikely. For pelvic girdle pain in pregnancy, corticosteroid injections are only used if other treatment modalities are ineffective.

C) INCORRECT:

Bed rest and fetal heart rate monitoring are indicated in hemodynamically stable patients with placental abruption and normal fetal findings up to 36 weeks' gestation. Although placental abruption may manifest with lower back pain, the onset is usually sudden, and patients typically present with additional findings, such as uterine contractions, vaginal bleeding, and fetal distress. While getting enough rest is also encouraged for patients with pelvic girdle pain, bed rest alone is not sufficient.

D) INCORRECT:

Periradicular therapy is a conservative treatment option for chronic lumbar radiculopathy, which can manifest with weakness of the legs and lower back pain. However, pelvic pain provocation tests are positive in this patient, which is not typical for lumbar radiculopathy. Moreover, additional findings, such as decreased foot dorsiflexion and patellar reflex as well as lower extremity paresthesia, would also be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Intravenous glucocorticoid (e.g., dexamethasone) therapy is used in the treatment of spinal cord compression, which can also manifest with radicular symptoms (e.g., weakness of the legs) or lower back pain that radiates to the posterior thighs or to the lower part of the abdomen. However, pelvic pain provocation tests are positive in this patient, which is not typical for spinal cord compression. Moreover, other neurologic deficits, such as urinary retention, bowel incontinence, weakness, sensation changes, and abnormal reflexes, would also be expected.
questions.hint: In a pregnant woman, lower back pain radiating to the posterior thigh, together with pubic symphysis pain and positive pelvic pain provocation tests (e.g., FABER test, active straight leg raise) suggests pelvic girdle pain.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman visits her primary care physician to discuss plans to conceive in the coming months. She works as a day care teacher and has a history of up-to-date routine immunizations. She is concerned about contracting influenza during pregnancy and asks about the timing of vaccination. Physical examination is normal. She plans to attempt conception this fall, coinciding with influenza season.
Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation regarding influenza vaccination for this patient?

choices.text: Postpone vaccination until the second trimester
No influenza vaccine until after delivery

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The live-attenuated intranasal influenza vaccine is contraindicated in pregnant women and those planning pregnancy due to theoretical risks of viral replication affecting the fetus. The inactivated influenza vaccine is recommended instead, as it is safe and effective for women planning conception.

B) CORRECT:

The inactivated influenza vaccine, composed of killed viral particles, is safe for administration before conception and during pregnancy. It provides protective immunity to the mother and passive immunity to the fetus through transplacental IgG transfer. This is crucial for individuals at increased risk of exposure, such as daycare teachers. The vaccine is recommended at any stage of pregnancy, making it suitable for preconception administration to optimize maternal and neonatal health during influenza season.

Key learning point: The influenza vaccine is recommended during the preconception period, especially if pregnancy will occur during the influenza season, to protect both the mother and the future baby from influenza-related complications.

C) INCORRECT:

Delaying vaccination until the second trimester is unnecessary, as the inactivated influenza vaccine is safe at any pregnancy stage. Waiting prolongs vulnerability to influenza, especially since pregnant patients face higher morbidity risks. Current guidelines recommend vaccination as soon as possible to ensure protection.

D) INCORRECT:

Delaying vaccination until after delivery leaves the mother and fetus unprotected during a high-risk period. The inactivated influenza vaccine is safe during all trimesters and reduces severe influenza-related complications in pregnant women. Vaccination before or during pregnancy is beneficial and safe.

questions.text: A 24-year-old pregnant woman, 12 weeks along with uncertain vaccination history, asks about preventing neonatal tetanus. Which measure is most effective in this situation?

choices.text: Provide maternal intramuscular tetanus immunoglobulin at 28 weeks
Delay tetanus immunization until labor begins
Administer recommended maternal tetanus toxoid doses
Give newborn tetanus toxoid injection at birth

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tetanus immunoglobulin provides temporary protection but does not stimulate active immune response or long-lived antibody production. For neonatal tetanus prevention, sustained maternal antibody levels from active immunization are needed for effective transplacental transfer.

B) INCORRECT:

Delaying tetanus immunization until labor does not allow sufficient time for maternal antibody production and transplacental transfer. Early immunization during the first or early second trimester is crucial to ensure adequate antibody formation and fetal transfer, providing neonatal protection.

C) CORRECT:

Maternal immunization with tetanus toxoid induces the production of high-affinity IgG antibodies, which are transferred transplacentally to the fetus, providing effective neonatal protection against tetanus. The vaccine is administered in a series of doses to optimize antibody titers, with timing during pregnancy chosen to maximize placental transfer during the third trimester. This strategy significantly reduces neonatal tetanus incidence by ensuring the newborn inherits protective antibody levels necessary to neutralize tetanospasmin toxin.

Key learning point: To prevent tetanus neonatorum, immunize the mother with tetanus toxoid before or early in pregnancy to provide passive immunity to the newborn.

D) INCORRECT:

The neonatal immune system is immature at birth and cannot mount a rapid response to tetanus toxoid. Protection against neonatal tetanus is best achieved through passive immunity from maternal IgG antibodies transferred during pregnancy, not by direct neonatal immunization.

questions.text: An 8-week pregnant woman with irregular cycles needs accurate dating. Which ultrasound parameter provides the most reliable gestational age in the first trimester?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Crown-rump length (CRL) is the most accurate ultrasound parameter for dating pregnancies in the first trimester, particularly between 7 and 13 weeks of gestation. It measures the distance from the top of the fetus's head to the bottom of the torso. CRL is highly reliable due to the linear growth pattern of the embryo during early development. In cases of irregular menstrual cycles, CRL provides a standardized approach to accurately determine gestational age, with a narrow margin of error compared to other parameters.

Key learning point: Crown-rump length (CRL) is the most accurate ultrasound measurement for estimating gestational age in the first trimester.

B) INCORRECT:

Femur length is used in the second and third trimesters when long bones are developed. At 8 weeks, the femur is too small for reliable measurement, leading to potential inaccuracy in early pregnancy dating.

C) INCORRECT:

Biparietal diameter is used in the second trimester when cranial anatomy is developed. At 8 weeks, embryonic structures are too small for accurate measurement, making it unreliable for first trimester dating.

D) INCORRECT:

Mean gestational sac diameter (MSD) can be measured in very early pregnancy but is less reliable for dating due to variability in sac shape and measurement discrepancies. It has a wider margin of error compared to parameters that directly reflect embryonic growth, such as crown-rump length.

questions.text: An 18-year-old primigravida with irregular cycles is unsure of her last menstrual period. She is estimated to be about 12 weeks pregnant. What is the most accurate test for confirming her gestational age?

choices.text: Serial serum beta-human chorionic gonadotropin measurements

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (beta-hCG) levels are useful for confirming pregnancy and assessing viability but are not precise for dating due to inter-individual variability. Serial beta-hCG measurements cannot accurately determine gestational age compared to anatomical assessments like crown-rump length.

B) CORRECT:

The crown-rump length (CRL) measurement in the first trimester is the most accurate method for dating a pregnancy, especially when menstrual cycles are irregular or the last menstrual period is uncertain. During this period, the embryo's growth is predictable and uniform, allowing CRL to accurately reflect gestational age. This measurement is typically performed between 7 and 14 weeks of gestation, minimizing measurement error and providing a reliable reference for obstetric management.

Key learning point: The most accurate time to confirm gestational age via ultrasound is during the first trimester, specifically between 11-13 weeks, using the crown-rump length measurement.

C) INCORRECT:

Last menstrual period-based dating assumes regular cycles and accurate recall, which is unreliable in patients with irregular cycles. Variability in ovulation timing and uncertainty about the last period can lead to inaccurate gestational age estimations.

D) INCORRECT:

The biparietal diameter (BPD) is measured during the mid-second trimester (around 18–22 weeks) and is subject to greater variability due to fetal head shape differences. In early pregnancy, first-trimester measurements like the crown-rump length provide more precise dating due to uniform embryonic growth.

questions.text: At 39 weeks, a 37-year-old G2P1 has a biophysical profile score of 6/10 and a reactive nonstress test. She is asymptomatic with normal vitals. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While a reactive NST and asymptomatic mother might suggest no immediate intervention, a BPP score of 6/10 is concerning at term. This score indicates potential uteroplacental insufficiency, warranting intervention rather than expectant management, to prevent fetal compromise.

B) CORRECT:

The biophysical profile (BPP) evaluates fetal well-being through five parameters: nonstress test (NST), fetal breathing movements, gross fetal movements, fetal tone, and amniotic fluid volume. A score of 6/10, despite a reactive NST, indicates suboptimal conditions in one or more areas. At 39 weeks, a BPP score below 8 suggests potential placental insufficiency and fetal compromise. Given the term gestation and borderline BPP, induction of labor is appropriate to mitigate risks and ensure fetal safety.

Key learning point: A biophysical profile score (BPS) of 8/10 or 10/10 is considered reassuring, indicating fetal well-being, while a score of 6/10 is equivocal and may require further evaluation.

C) INCORRECT:

Umbilical artery Doppler velocimetry assesses placental circulation resistance, useful in preterm growth-restricted pregnancies. At 39 weeks with a reactive NST, the term gestation and potential for delivery reduce the utility of Doppler studies, as they do not alter immediate management.

D) INCORRECT:

A contraction stress test (CST) is used when a nonreactive NST raises concerns about fetal well-being. This patient has a reactive NST, indicating adequate fetal oxygenation, making CST unnecessary. At 39 weeks, with normal maternal vitals and a reactive NST, noninvasive management is preferred over CST, which may introduce unnecessary risks.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old G2P1 woman presents to the Outpatient Clinic for prenatal care. She is unsure of her last menstrual period and has not had any prenatal evaluations. Her only complaint is mild nausea. She has no chronic medical conditions. A transvaginal ultrasound shows a single intrauterine embryo at approximately 9 weeks of gestation. Laboratory evaluation is normal.
Which ultrasound measurement parameter is most accurate for determining gestational age in the first trimester?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mean gestational sac diameter is used in very early pregnancy before the embryo is visible. Once the embryo is identifiable, embryonic measurements like crown-rump length provide more accurate gestational dating due to less variability and greater precision.

B) INCORRECT:

Biparietal diameter (BPD) is more accurate in the second trimester when the fetal skull is better defined. In the first trimester, the fetal head undergoes rapid development, making it difficult to consistently identify landmarks for accurate BPD measurement. This variability reduces its reliability for early gestational dating.

C) INCORRECT:

Femur length is used in the second and third trimesters to assess fetal growth. In the first trimester, the femur is not sufficiently ossified or consistently visualized for precise measurement, making it unreliable for early gestational dating.

D) CORRECT:

Crown-rump length (CRL) is the most accurate ultrasound measurement for determining gestational age in the first trimester, specifically between 7 and 13 weeks. It measures the embryo from the top of the head to the bottom of the buttocks, reflecting a consistent growth pattern during early fetal development. This precision is particularly useful when the last menstrual period is uncertain, providing a reliable estimate for gestational dating and supporting appropriate prenatal care.

Key learning point: Crown-rump length is the most accurate ultrasound measurement for determining gestational age in the first trimester.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman presenting for prenatal care reports her last menstrual period began on July 7. Which method best computes her expected date of delivery?

choices.text: Add 7 days, subtract 3 months, and add 1 year
Add 7 days, subtract 2 months, and add 1 year
Subtract 7 days, subtract 3 months, and add 1 year

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Naegele’s rule estimates the expected date of delivery by assuming a 280-day gestation period from the first day of the last menstrual period (LMP). This method involves adding 7 days to the LMP, subtracting 3 months, and adding 1 year. This calculation accounts for a typical 28-day menstrual cycle, where ovulation occurs approximately 14 days after the LMP. The addition of 1 year ensures the expected delivery date falls in the correct calendar year, providing a systematic approach to estimate gestational age and plan prenatal care.

Key learning point: Naegele's rule is used to estimate the date of delivery by adding 7 days to the first day of the last menstrual period and subtracting 3 months.

B) INCORRECT:

Subtracting 2 months instead of 3 results in a due date approximately one month later than the standard estimation. Naegele’s rule involves adding 7 days, subtracting 3 months, and adding 1 year to accurately estimate the expected date of delivery.

C) INCORRECT:

This method omits the crucial step of adding 1 year, leading to an incorrect expected delivery date within the same calendar year. Naegele’s rule requires adding 7 days, subtracting 3 months, and adding 1 year to account for a 280-day gestation period.

D) INCORRECT:

This method incorrectly subtracts 7 days, disrupting the sequence of Naegele’s rule. The correct sequence is to add 7 days, subtract 3 months, and add 1 year, ensuring an accurate estimation of the expected date of delivery.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old G2P1 woman at 39 weeks’ gestation is admitted to the Labor Unit with regular contractions. A rectovaginal culture at 36 weeks was positive for group B streptococci. She has no known medication allergies. Her cervix is dilated to 5 cm, and membranes ruptured spontaneously an hour ago with clear fluid. Vital signs are stable, and continuous fetal monitoring shows normal tracings.
Which of the following is the most appropriate intrapartum management to reduce the risk of early-onset GBS disease in her newborn?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral amoxicillin, while effective against GBS, is unsuitable for intrapartum prophylaxis due to its slower absorption and less reliable therapeutic levels. Intravenous administration is preferred to rapidly achieve effective maternal and fetal serum concentrations, ensuring timely bacterial suppression during labor.

B) CORRECT:

Intravenous ampicillin is the standard intrapartum prophylaxis for group B streptococcus (GBS) colonization to prevent early-onset neonatal sepsis. Ampicillin, a beta-lactam antibiotic, disrupts bacterial cell wall synthesis and is effective against gram-positive organisms like GBS. Administering it intravenously during labor ensures rapid therapeutic levels, minimizing vertical transmission. Guidelines from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) recommend this approach for GBS-positive women without beta-lactam allergies, as it provides reliable bioavailability and optimal pharmacologic action during the critical intrapartum period.

Key learning point: Intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis with Ampicillin is recommended for pregnant women who are Group-B streptococci positive to prevent early-onset GBS disease in the newborn.

C) INCORRECT:

Forgoing antibiotic prophylaxis is inappropriate for a GBS-positive patient, as it increases the risk of early-onset neonatal infections. Established guidelines recommend antibiotics for GBS-positive women to prevent neonatal sepsis, pneumonia, and meningitis, especially when no contraindications exist.

D) INCORRECT:

Intravenous vancomycin is reserved for patients with severe beta-lactam allergies. This patient has no known allergies, making beta-lactam antibiotics like penicillin the preferred choice. Vancomycin's broader spectrum and resistance risk make it less suitable when beta-lactams are an option.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old pregnant woman presents for a routine ultrasound evaluation at 12 weeks gestation. Sonographic findings reveal a single live intrauterine pregnancy with a fluid-filled structure in the fetal neck region consistent with cystic hygroma. She has no significant past medical history and denies any known genetic conditions in her family (see report).
Ultrasound: Single live intrauterine pregnancy with a fluid-filled structure in the fetal neck region consistent with cystic hygroma
Which of the following diagnostic procedures is most appropriate for definitive testing for potential chromosomal abnormalities at this stage?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Noninvasive prenatal testing (NIPT) analyzes cell-free fetal DNA in maternal blood to assess chromosomal anomalies. While highly sensitive and specific, it is a screening tool, not diagnostic. For definitive diagnosis, direct fetal genetic material analysis, such as through chorionic villus sampling, is required.

B) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous umbilical cord blood sampling, or cordocentesis, is typically performed after 18 weeks of gestation due to technical challenges and increased risk of complications in early pregnancy. It is not suitable for a 12-week gestation when safer options like chorionic villus sampling are available.

C) INCORRECT:

Amniocentesis provides definitive chromosomal analysis but is typically performed starting at 15 weeks of gestation. At 12 weeks, the amniotic fluid volume is insufficient for safe sampling, increasing procedural difficulty and risk. Therefore, it is not suitable for early gestational age.

D) CORRECT:

Cystic hygroma detected on a first-trimester ultrasound is strongly associated with chromosomal abnormalities, such as Turner syndrome and trisomies. Chorionic villus sampling (CVS) is performed between 10 and 13 weeks of gestation, making it suitable for this 12-week gestation. CVS involves obtaining placental tissue, which contains fetal cells for karyotyping, allowing early and definitive diagnosis of chromosomal abnormalities. This early diagnostic capability is crucial for providing comprehensive counseling and management options.

Key learning point: Chorionic villus sampling is the appropriate diagnostic test for chromosomal abnormalities in a fetus with cystic hygroma at 12 weeks of gestation.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old primigravida is 32 weeks pregnant and has attended routine prenatal visits every 4 weeks for the last 6 months. She has had no complications. She expresses concern about frequent travel for appointments due to her work schedule.

Blood pressure
110/70 mm Hg

Which of the following schedules is most appropriate at this time?

choices.text: Every 4 weeks until 36 weeks, then weekly
Weekly visits starting now until delivery
Every 2 weeks until 36 weeks, then weekly
No visits until 36 weeks, then every 2 weeks

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Continuing 4-week intervals until 36 weeks does not align with standard prenatal care guidelines, which recommend biweekly visits from 28 to 36 weeks. This increased frequency is crucial for monitoring potential complications that can arise in the third trimester, despite the patient's current lack of complications.

B) INCORRECT:

Weekly visits are typically reserved for high-risk pregnancies or the final weeks of gestation. In a low-risk pregnancy at 32 weeks, biweekly visits are sufficient until 36 weeks, when weekly visits become necessary. This approach avoids unnecessary inconvenience and resource use.

C) CORRECT:

In an uncomplicated pregnancy, prenatal care is adjusted to monitor maternal and fetal health as gestation progresses. From 28 to 36 weeks, biweekly visits are recommended to detect potential complications like preeclampsia or preterm labor. After 36 weeks, weekly visits are advised to closely monitor growth, blood pressure, and fetal activity. This schedule balances patient convenience with the need for increased surveillance as the pregnancy approaches term.

Key learning point: In an uncomplicated pregnancy at 32 weeks gestation, routine follow-up visits every 2 weeks are standard practice to monitor maternal and fetal health.

D) INCORRECT:

Delaying visits until 36 weeks omits a critical period for monitoring rapid maternal and fetal changes. Biweekly visits from 28 to 36 weeks are recommended to screen for conditions like gestational hypertension and fetal growth anomalies, ensuring timely detection of complications.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old G2P1 woman presents to the clinic at approximately 8 weeks of gestation. She reports an irregular last menstrual period and is uncertain of the date. She has not started prenatal care or had any imaging. Physical examination shows a gravid uterus with no obvious abnormalities. She wants to determine her due date as accurately as possible.
Which of the following methods is most reliable for dating her pregnancy at this time?

choices.text: Uterine size assessment via physical examination
Calculation based on last menstrual period
First-trimester ultrasound measurement of crown-rump length
Second-trimester ultrasound measurement of biparietal diameter

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In early pregnancy, the uterus is primarily a pelvic organ with minimal enlargement, making clinical estimation by physical exam imprecise. Variability in uterine size due to anatomical differences and maternal body habitus further limits accuracy in gestational dating at approximately 8 weeks.

B) INCORRECT:

Dating a pregnancy based on the last menstrual period (LMP) is less reliable when the patient is uncertain of the date or has irregular cycles. This method assumes a 28-day cycle with ovulation on day 14, which may not apply to all individuals, leading to potential errors in gestational age estimation.

C) CORRECT:

The crown-rump length (CRL) measured via first-trimester ultrasound is the most reliable method for dating pregnancy up to 13 weeks. This measurement, from the top of the embryo's head to the bottom of its torso, correlates closely with embryonic development due to uniform growth during this period. The error margin is minimal, typically within a few days, making it ideal when menstrual history is uncertain. Accurate gestational age determination allows for better timing of prenatal evaluations and interventions.

Key learning point: Crown-rump length measured by ultrasound in the first trimester is the most reliable method for dating a pregnancy.

D) INCORRECT:

The biparietal diameter (BPD) is measured between 18 and 22 weeks of gestation and is less precise for dating early pregnancy due to individual variability in fetal head growth. Early pregnancy dating is more accurately achieved with first-trimester measurements like the crown-rump length.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old woman presents to the Outpatient Clinic for her first prenatal exam. She has unpredictable menstrual cycles and reports a positive home pregnancy test 2 weeks ago but is uncertain of her last menstrual period. Transvaginal ultrasound at approximately 9 weeks shows a single intrauterine gestation with a demonstrable fetal heartbeat. 
Which of the following measurements is the best method for accurately establishing her gestational age?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Crown-rump length (CRL) is the most accurate method for dating a pregnancy in the first trimester, specifically between 6 and 13 weeks of gestation. During this period, fetal growth is consistent. CRL measures the distance from the crown to the rump, providing a standard growth metric with minimal variability. Accurate dating is crucial for prenatal care management, ensuring appropriate timing for interventions and screenings.

Key learning point: Crown-rump length (CRL) is the most accurate parameter for dating pregnancy in the first trimester.

B) INCORRECT:

Mean gestational sac diameter (mGSD) estimates gestational age in very early pregnancies before the fetal heartbeat is visualized. In this case, a more accurate dating method can be used.

C) INCORRECT:

Biparietal diameter (BPD) is used for fetal dating during the mid-second trimester when the fetal skull is well formed. At approximately 9 weeks, the fetal head structures are not fully developed, making BPD unreliable for dating.

D) INCORRECT:

Femur length is used in the second and third trimesters to assess fetal growth. At approximately 9 weeks, the fetal femur is very small, and its measurement is variable, reducing its accuracy for dating.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old G2P1 woman at 30 weeks’ gestation presents to the clinic with regular painful contractions. She has had no prenatal care and is uncertain of her group B streptococcus status. She denies any drug allergies. Examination shows her cervix is effaced and dilated to 3 cm. Fetal heart rate tracing is reassuring. Tocolysis is being initiated, and betamethasone has been administered for fetal lung maturity.
Which of the following is the most appropriate step to reduce the risk of neonatal group B streptococcal infection in this patient?

choices.text: Defer antibiotic prophylaxis unless GBS culture is positive

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral amoxicillin, although effective against group B Streptococcus, does not achieve the rapid and consistent maternal serum concentrations required for intrapartum prophylaxis. Oral administration leads to variable absorption and pharmacokinetics, insufficient for timely therapeutic levels during labor. The intravenous route is necessary for immediate antibiotic levels critical during labor.

B) CORRECT:

Intravenous penicillin G is the standard intrapartum prophylactic antibiotic to prevent vertical transmission of group B Streptococcus (GBS) during labor, especially when GBS status is unknown. Administering IV penicillin G reduces the risk of neonatal GBS infection by targeting the bacteria at its transmission source during delivery. Clinical guidelines recommend intrapartum antibiotic prophylaxis in women in preterm labor, as early-onset GBS disease is a major cause of neonatal morbidity and mortality. Penicillin G's narrow spectrum and efficacy in clearing GBS from the maternal genital tract decrease the risk of neonatal sepsis, pneumonia, and meningitis.

Key learning point: In preterm labor at 30 weeks gestation, management includes administering corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity, tocolytics to delay labor, and GBS prophylaxis to prevent neonatal infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone, a broad-spectrum cephalosporin, is not aligned with intrapartum prophylaxis protocols for GBS. Effective prophylaxis requires intravenous administration to rapidly achieve therapeutic serum levels. Intramuscular injections result in delayed and less predictable concentrations, which is suboptimal during labor. Guidelines recommend beta-lactam agents like penicillin for patients without allergies.

D) INCORRECT:

Deferring antibiotic prophylaxis until a positive GBS culture is confirmed is inappropriate in preterm labor with unknown GBS status. Delaying prophylaxis can miss the window for effective intrapartum antibiotic administration, exposing the neonate to GBS infection risks. Guidelines advocate for prophylaxis in patients with risk factors like preterm labor or unknown GBS colonization.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman presents to the Outpatient Clinic for her first prenatal visit. She has irregular menses but believes she may be about 10 weeks pregnant. On physical examination, her uterine size appears consistent with early pregnancy. Ultrasonography shows an intrauterine pregnancy and normal fetal cardiac activity.
Which of the following is the most relevant information to establish the gestational age in this patient?

choices.text: Quantitative serum beta-human chorionic gonadotropin level

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Using the reported last menstrual period (LMP) for dating is unreliable in patients with irregular cycles or uncertain LMP, as it can lead to significant errors. Irregular menses complicate the estimation of cycle length and ovulation timing, making LMP-derived dating imprecise in this context.

B) INCORRECT:

A single quantitative beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (beta-hCG) level is not reliable for gestational dating due to significant variability in hCG levels between individuals and stages of gestation. This variability, along with the exponential increase in early pregnancy, limits its accuracy for determining gestational age.

C) CORRECT:

First-trimester ultrasound measurement of crown-rump length (CRL) is the most accurate method for dating a pregnancy, particularly when menstrual history is uncertain. During the first trimester, embryonic growth is consistent, allowing CRL measurements to accurately estimate gestational age with minimal error. This method is typically performed between 7 and 13 weeks of gestation and is considered the gold standard for establishing gestational age in cases with unreliable menstrual history.

Key learning point: Crown-rump length (CRL) measured by ultrasound is the most accurate method for dating a pregnancy in the first trimester, especially when the last menstrual period is uncertain due to irregular menses.

D) INCORRECT:

Biparietal diameter (BPD) is a reliable measurement in the second trimester, typically after 14 weeks, when fetal head development is sufficient. At approximately 10 weeks, crown-rump length is the preferred metric for dating, as BPD is not applicable due to incomplete fetal anatomical development.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old primigravida presents to the Outpatient Clinic at 10 weeks of gestation for a routine prenatal visit. Her first-trimester ultrasound was normal, and all initial screening tests, including maternal serum markers, were within normal limits. Her obstetrician discusses the recommended timeline for evaluation of fetal anatomy to screen for structural anomalies.
At what gestational age is a detailed fetal anomaly scan typically performed to optimize detection of congenital malformations?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While 24–26 weeks falls within the second trimester, the optimal window for a detailed fetal anomaly scan is 18–22 weeks. At 24–26 weeks, factors like reduced amniotic fluid relative to fetal size and increased fetal crowding can obscure anatomical details, decreasing image quality. Additionally, later scanning narrows the window for subsequent evaluation and management if abnormalities are detected.

B) INCORRECT:

The 11–13 week period is suitable for first-trimester assessments like nuchal translucency measurement and gestational dating confirmation. However, it is not ideal for a comprehensive structural evaluation due to the incomplete development of many anatomical structures, limiting the detection of detailed congenital malformations.

C) CORRECT:

The detailed fetal anomaly scan is optimally performed between 18 and 22 weeks of gestation. During this period, fetal organ systems are sufficiently developed for comprehensive anatomical evaluation. High-resolution ultrasound can clearly visualize critical structures such as the heart, brain, spine, and limbs, enhancing the detection of congenital malformations. This timing allows for detailed imaging and assessment of structural details and vascular flow, improving diagnostic accuracy. Additionally, it provides ample time for follow-up evaluations and management decisions if anomalies are identified.

Key learning point: The optimal time for a detailed fetal anomaly scan is between 18-22 weeks of gestation, as this period allows for the best visualization of fetal structures to identify potential congenital anomalies.

D) INCORRECT:

At 16 weeks, fetal structures are still developing, making it premature for optimal visualization in a detailed anomaly scan. Many anatomical details may not be fully formed or easily appreciated on ultrasound. The optimal window for comprehensive assessment is between 18–22 weeks, when fetal growth and organogenesis are more advanced.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old G2P1 woman at 36 weeks’ gestation presents to the clinic with a noticeable decrease in fetal movements over the last 8 hours. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated, and fetal growth was appropriate on an ultrasound at 34 weeks. She has no contractions or leakage of fluid. Vital signs are stable, and fundal height measures 36 cm. The fetal heart rate is 140 beats per minute on handheld Doppler.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound with Doppler velocimetry assesses placental blood flow and is used when there is evidence of growth restriction or placental insufficiency. The normal fetal heart rate and appropriate growth in this patient reduce the likelihood of placental insufficiency, making this test less appropriate initially.

B) INCORRECT:

Immediate induction of labor is considered when there is evidence of fetal compromise, such as abnormal heart rate patterns or oligohydramnios. In this patient, the normal fetal heart rate and absence of distress signs do not warrant induction without further diagnostic testing.

C) INCORRECT:

The contraction stress test evaluates fetal heart rate response to induced contractions, assessing uteroplacental sufficiency. It is typically used when a non-stress test is non-reactive. In this patient, the reassuring fetal heart rate and absence of contractions make the contraction stress test unnecessary.

D) CORRECT:

The non-stress test (NST) is a noninvasive method to assess fetal well-being, especially when decreased fetal movements are reported. It monitors the fetal heart rate over 20-40 minutes, looking for accelerations that indicate adequate oxygenation and intact neurological function. A reactive NST, with at least two accelerations, suggests proper fetal autonomic function and sufficient placental oxygen transfer. In a stable 36-week gestation patient with a normal fetal heart rate, the NST provides an objective evaluation of fetal status.

Key learning point: In cases of reduced fetal movements at 36 weeks of gestation, the most appropriate immediate step is to perform a CTG to assess fetal well-being and detect any signs of fetal distress.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old primigravida at 34 weeks’ gestation presents to the clinic with decreased fetal movements for the past 12 hours. Physical examination is normal, and vital signs are stable. Initial cardiotocography shows reduced variability but no decelerations. After oral hydration and continued monitoring for several hours, fetal heart rate variability improves, and the patient reports feeling more fetal movements (see report).
Ultrasound: Unremarkable
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discharge with a daily fetal kick chart for ongoing monitoring

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Immediate induction of labor is considered when there is persistent fetal compromise unresponsive to conservative measures. In this patient, fetal heart rate variability improved with hydration, and fetal movements increased, indicating no sustained compromise. Induction at 34 weeks carries risks and is reserved for ongoing fetal distress.

B) INCORRECT:

Doppler ultrasound assesses uteroplacental blood flow, useful in cases of persistent non-reassuring fetal heart rate patterns. This patient showed improved fetal heart rate variability and increased movements after hydration, with an unremarkable ultrasound, indicating no need for urgent Doppler evaluation.

C) CORRECT:

Decreased fetal movements in the third trimester require evaluation with cardiotocography and ultrasound. In this patient, initial reduced fetal heart rate variability improved with oral hydration and monitoring, suggesting a transient issue. The unremarkable ultrasound indicates no persistent fetal distress. Daily fetal kick counts provide effective outpatient surveillance, allowing early detection of decreased fetal movements and avoiding unnecessary interventions.

Key learning point: In cases of decreased fetal movement with initial poor CTG variability that improves with hydration and monitoring, discharge with a fetal kick chart is appropriate if no other concerns are present.

D) INCORRECT:

Prolonged inpatient monitoring is warranted for persistent fetal distress, such as ongoing reduced heart rate variability or recurrent decelerations. This patient showed improvement in fetal heart rate variability and movements after hydration, with an unremarkable ultrasound, indicating a transient issue rather than ongoing distress.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old pregnant woman, G2P1, at 34 weeks’ gestation presents to the clinic with concern of decreased fetal movements over the last day. Her prenatal course has been uncomplicated, and she denies any leakage of fluid, vaginal bleeding, or contractions. She has no significant medical history. Maternal blood pressure is normal. Fetal heart tones are present but unremarkable on handheld Doppler.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A contraction stress test (CST) evaluates fetal heart rate response to uterine contractions, assessing uteroplacental insufficiency. It is not a first-line test for decreased fetal movement, as it involves inducing contractions, which can pose risks. CST is reserved for nonreactive NST results or suspected placental compromise.

B) CORRECT:

A non-stress test (NST) is the appropriate initial step for assessing fetal well-being when decreased fetal movements are reported. The NST evaluates fetal heart rate in response to fetal movements, providing insight into fetal oxygenation and autonomic nervous system integrity. At 34 weeks’ gestation, the presence of reactive accelerations on the NST is reassuring. The test is non-invasive, easy to perform, and provides prompt results, making it an ideal first-line evaluation tool in this context.

Key learning point: In cases of decreased fetal movement, a non-stress test is the initial step to assess fetal well-being.

C) INCORRECT:

A biophysical profile (BPP) combines fetal heart rate assessment with ultrasound evaluations of fetal breathing, movement, tone, and amniotic fluid volume. It is more comprehensive but typically reserved for cases where initial tests suggest potential compromise or when additional risk factors are present. In the absence of concerning findings, a simpler initial assessment like a non-stress test is preferred.

D) INCORRECT:

Inducing labor is considered when there is significant evidence of fetal compromise or maternal indications. In this scenario, decreased fetal movements without abnormal fetal heart rate findings or maternal instability do not warrant immediate induction, especially at 34 weeks’ gestation, where prematurity is a concern.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old G2P1 woman at 37 weeks’ gestation with diet-controlled gestational diabetes undergoes a biophysical profile for routine antepartum surveillance. She denies contractions and perceives good fetal movement. Vital signs are stable. Physical examination is normal (see report).
Biophysical profile: Normal amniotic fluid volume, reactive nonstress test, normal fetal movements, normal fetal tone, decreased fetal breathing movements, total score of 8 out of 10
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain a Doppler velocimetry study of the umbilical artery
Repeat the biophysical profile in 1 week

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A contraction stress test (CST) assesses fetal heart rate response to contractions, useful in nonreactive nonstress tests or borderline BPPs. However, with a BPP score of 8 out of 10, including a reactive nonstress test and normal amniotic fluid volume, further testing is unnecessary. The isolated finding of decreased fetal breathing movements does not warrant a CST.

B) INCORRECT:

Umbilical artery Doppler velocimetry evaluates placental insufficiency, particularly in intrauterine growth restriction or abnormal BPPs. In this case, the BPP score is 8 out of 10, with normal amniotic fluid volume and fetal movements, indicating adequate placental function. The decreased fetal breathing movements alone do not justify this study.

C) CORRECT:

The biophysical profile (BPP) evaluates fetal well-being through five components: fetal breathing movements, gross fetal movements, fetal tone, amniotic fluid volume, and the nonstress test. A score of 8 out of 10, with decreased fetal breathing movements as the only abnormality, suggests a reassuring fetal status. Decreased fetal breathing movements can be transient and are not indicative of fetal compromise when other parameters are normal. In a 37-week gestation with controlled gestational diabetes and no distress signs, repeating the BPP in 1 week is appropriate for ongoing surveillance.

Key learning point: A biophysical profile score of 8-10 is considered reassuring, and in the absence of fetal distress, routine monitoring with a repeat biophysical profile in 1 week is appropriate.

D) INCORRECT:

Induction of labor is not indicated with a BPP score of 8 out of 10, as decreased fetal breathing movements can be transient and not indicative of fetal compromise. The patient's gestational diabetes is diet-controlled, and other BPP components are reassuring, making immediate delivery unnecessary.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents to the Outpatient Clinic for her first prenatal visit. She reports a long history of irregular menstrual cycles and cannot recall her last menstrual period. She has experienced mild breast tenderness and fatigue for an uncertain duration. A urine pregnancy test is positive. Physical examination is consistent with early pregnancy, but her exact gestational age is unclear.
What is the most accurate method to establish this patient's gestational age?

choices.text: Transabdominal ultrasound in the second trimester
Serial quantitative beta-human chorionic gonadotropin levels
Transvaginal ultrasound measurement early in the first trimester

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transabdominal ultrasound in the second trimester uses biometric parameters to estimate gestational age, but these are subject to greater variability. In cases of uncertain menstrual history, early first-trimester ultrasound measurements, such as crown-rump length, offer more precise dating due to a narrower margin of error.

B) INCORRECT:

Physical exam-based uterine sizing is subjective and influenced by factors like maternal habitus and anatomical differences. In early pregnancy, the uterus is a small pelvic organ, making it difficult to provide a reliable gestational age estimation compared to methods that directly measure embryonic or fetal dimensions.

C) INCORRECT:

Serial quantitative beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (β-hCG) measurements assess early pregnancy viability but have significant biological variability, limiting their accuracy in determining gestational age. β-hCG reflects placental development rather than direct embryonic growth, making it less precise than early first-trimester ultrasound measurements for dating pregnancy.

D) CORRECT:

Transvaginal ultrasound in the first trimester, specifically measuring the crown-rump length (CRL), is the most accurate method for dating pregnancy when the last menstrual period is uncertain. The CRL provides a reliable marker due to predictable embryonic growth, with an error margin of approximately 5–7 days. This method is endorsed by professional guidelines for precise gestational age estimation, ensuring accurate obstetric management.

Key learning point: In cases where the last menstrual period is unknown or unreliable, a transvaginal ultrasound performed early in the first trimester is the most accurate method for determining gestational age and estimating the date of delivery.

questions.text: You are seeing a 37-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 13 weeks' gestation for a prenatal visit. She reports feeling well. Her only medication is folic acid. Vital signs are normal. Pelvic examination reveals a uterus consistent in size with a 13-week gestation. Ultrasonography shows a nuchal translucency above the 99th percentile. Maternal serum pregnancy-associated plasma protein A is decreased, and human chorionic gonadotropin is elevated to 2 times the median level. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cell-free fetal DNA (cffDNA) testing of maternal blood can be used to screen for fetal aneuploidies. Because of its low false-positive rate for Down syndrome, cffDNA testing is commonly used as a secondary screening test in patients at high risk (e.g., maternal age ≥ 35 years, abnormal first-trimester screening results) in order to avoid invasive procedures. However, cffDNA testing is not diagnostic and fetal chromosomal analysis using an invasive test is still required to confirm Down syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Amniocentesis is indicated as a prenatal diagnostic procedure to further evaluate for fetal genetic abnormalities in patients with abnormal screening results. However, it is usually only performed at 15–20 weeks of gestation, as it is associated with a high risk of complications in the first trimester. This patient is only 13 weeks pregnant and should therefore not undergo amniocentesis.

C) CORRECT:

Chorionic villus sampling for fetal chromosomal analysis is the method of choice to confirm fetal aneuploidy at 10 to 13 weeks' gestation and should be offered to all patients at increased risk (e.g., abnormal first-trimester screening, maternal age ≥ 35 years, previous child with a chromosomal anomaly). From the 15th week of pregnancy onward, amniocentesis is the preferred method for prenatal genetic diagnosis.

Key learning point: Chorionic villus sampling is the preferred diagnostic test for confirming fetal chromosomal abnormalities, such as Down syndrome, between 10 and 13 weeks of gestation.

D) INCORRECT:

The quadruple marker test is performed at 15–22 weeks' gestation and involves measurements of alpha-fetoprotein, unconjugated estriol, β-hCG, and inhibin A in maternal serum to screen for fetal chromosomal disorders. Since this patient's first-trimester screening already indicated a risk for Down syndrome, more definitive testing rather than further screening should be performed.

E) INCORRECT:

The triple screening test takes into account serum levels of α-fetoprotein, unconjugated estriol, and β-hCG (free or total). It should be performed in the second trimester, usually between 15–22 weeks of gestation. Since this patient's first-trimester screening already indicated a risk for Down syndrome, more definitive testing rather than further screening should be performed.
questions.hint: Increased nuchal translucency, elevated β-hCG levels, and decreased pregnancy-associated plasma protein A (PAPP-A) indicate a high risk of Down syndrome.

questions.text: You are seeing a 29-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 17 weeks' gestation for a routine prenatal visit. At 16 weeks' gestation, her serum studies showed an abnormally elevated alpha-fetoprotein level, with normal beta-human chorionic gonadotropin and estriol levels. After genetic counseling, she chooses to continue the pregnancy without further diagnostic testing. The remainder of her pregnancy is uncomplicated, and she delivers a boy at 38 weeks' gestation. Analysis of the infant's leukocytes shows a 46, XY karyotype. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of the abnormal triple test results?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Robertsonian translocation accounts for a minority of cases of Down syndrome, Patau syndrome, and Edwards syndrome and would be associated with a normal chromosomal number, as seen here. However, Down syndrome, Patau syndrome, and Edwards syndrome would usually result in decreased levels of AFP and estriol in maternal serum, and abnormal findings on first-trimester ultrasonography (e.g., increased nuchal translucency). The constellation of increased MSAFP, normal serum β-hCG and estriol, and normal first-trimester ultrasound has a different explanation.

B) CORRECT:

Incorrect estimation of the gestational age is the most common cause of abnormal MSAFP levels; in this case, the patient most likely underestimated the duration of her pregnancy. As a result, the MSAFP value was compared to the standardized mean for a 17-week-old fetus when, in actuality, the fetus was further along in development. Because AFP is synthesized by the fetal yolk sac, liver, and gastrointestinal tract, its concentration increases throughout pregnancy as the fetus grows. Thus, an inaccurate gestational age can cause the maternal serum level to appear abnormally low or high. Measurement of MSAFP is often combined with fetal ultrasound to ensure that the blood test is interpreted based on the correct gestational age.

Key learning point: Incorrect estimation of gestational age is the most common cause of abnormal maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein levels during pregnancy.

C) INCORRECT:

Congenital umbilical hernia is associated with normal MSAFP levels. It is caused by incomplete closure of the abdominal ring and commonly manifests as an asymptomatic, reducible, skin-covered bulge at the umbilicus. It is distinct from gastroschisis and omphalocele, both of which are abdominal wall defects that cause exposure and herniation of abdominal viscera as well as elevated MSAFP levels.

D) INCORRECT:

Although spina bifida (and other open neural tube defects) manifests with elevated MSAFP levels, spina bifida occulta is associated with a normal MSAFP. Because spina bifida occulta does not result in communication between the fetal tissue and the amniotic fluid, AFP cannot leak into the amnion. Neonates with this condition classically present with a tuft of hair or skin dimple at the level of the defect in the lumbar spine.

E) INCORRECT:

Gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD) would not result in a viable fetus. Moreover, GTD would have resulted in elevated serum β-hCG, decreased or normal MSAFP, and an intrauterine mass with multiple hypoechoic foci on ultrasonography. The constellation of normal serum β-hCG, increased MSAFP, normal first-trimester ultrasound, and viable term pregnancy has a different explanation.
questions.hint: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is produced by the fetus and can be measured in maternal serum (MSAFP), which continuously rises during the second trimester. While elevated MSAFP levels are associated with certain developmental defects that create pathological communications between the fetus and the amnion (e.g., abdominal wall defects, open neural tube defects), other benign factors may also lead to abnormal test results.

questions.text: You are caring for a 27-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 37 weeks' gestation who is admitted to the hospital in active labor. She has received routine prenatal care but has not been tested for group B streptococcal (GBS) colonization.
